PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Is it true that the agreement between the Queensland government and Suns Metal Corporation over the Korea Zinc Refinery on environmental risk management states that `The capacity of the zinc ferrite storage ponds is to be limited to 1.1 million cubic metres' and that `within seven years of the commissioning of the refinery, Suns Metal Corporation shall commission a reprocessing plant capable of reprocessing all zinc ferrite stored in the ponds'? The zinc refinery's impact assessment statement says categorically that `a plant for the processing of zinc ferrite will be installed at the Townsville plant.' Is this not a far cry from what you told the Senate in answer to a question I asked on 10 February, that ultimately the waste will be shipped back to Korea where it will go through a new process? Minister, why did you mislead the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not mislead the Senate. I think what you are doing is filling in the gaps. You are correct. The plan is—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just listen for a minute. If the process can be proved and implemented—this is as I recall—in Queensland, which has to be done within a period of seven years, then it would occur in Queensland. If it cannot be proved up—as I said to you, this process is being developed at the moment in Korea and, as I understand, it is not complete—then the wastes, as I recall it, will be transferred to Korea for reprocessing. I do not know whether you have all the EISs, but if you go back to the agreements with the Queensland government you will find that what I have just said to you is the exact and correct position.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you say that I am filling in the gaps, but I am not the Minister for the Environment. If you do not have a clue about what is going on in relation to this refinery, should you not revisit the environmental ramifications of seven‐year storage ponds close to wetland areas next to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous question you asked was to seek a comparison between what is required in Tasmania in relation to waste—and, at the moment, it is being dumped offshore, which was proved by our friend across here—and what is going to happen in Queensland. What I said to you is that the process that is to be adopted in Queensland is arguably better than that for Tasmania because ultimately all the waste is to be reprocessed. So that is a better outcome, which was the point I made on the last occasion.

ANSWER.PARA: There were very thorough environmental impact assessments made in relation to that plant. They took place over a long period of time and after careful examination they came up demonstrating a very high quality of environmental protection. That plant will be good for Queensland. It will provide jobs. It will be good for the Australian economy and will be built consistent with the highest environmental standards. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Heffernan, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy by noting that there has been a significant increase in exploration within the Australia‐Indonesia Zone of Cooperation (ZOCA) in the Timor Sea. Will the minister report on the success of Australia‐Indonesia Zone of Cooperation, particularly in relation to the activities of companies operating within this zone? Can the minister confirm reports that this area is about to enter a new phase of development?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I am afraid you can tell by the interjections that the Labor Party is not going to like this. It is more good news, and good news is something the Labor Party cannot hack. Well, they are going to have to get used to it.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to inform the Senate of the development of a new oil field in the Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation. The joint authority has declared the Elang Kakatua oil fields to be a discovery area and has authorised BHP Petroleum, the operator for the Elang Kakatua development, to develop these fields. BHP Petroleum announced, on 14 February, that it had decided to proceed with the commercial development. The initial development will involve the use of three subsea wells with flow lines linked to a floating production, storage and off‐loading vessel. The Elang Kakatua development—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are called FPSOs, Warwick.

—Senator Bob Collins was great on acronyms, as you might recall, but I think the general public do not understand them, so I am not inclined to use them. The Elang Kakatua development may be used for the development of other projects in the area. It is located in the production sharing contract zone of cooperation A91‐12, which is held by BHP Petroleum 42.42 per cent, Santos 21.42 per cent, Petroz 14.95 per cent and Inpex Sahul Ltd 21.21 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The Undan gas condensate discovery is also in the production‐sharing contract area, as is the Bayu gas condensate discovery, which is held by Phillips Petroleum 60 per cent, Oryx 25 per cent and Hardy Timor Gap Petroleum 15 per cent. Bayu and Undan are expected to be declared discovery areas by the joint authority this year.BHP Petroleum is investigating the viability of development via an offshore LNG processing facility, either in the zone of cooperation or just outside it. Phillips is investigating the viability of development via an LNG plant onshore at Darwin, and the first LNG cargoes are possible by the year 2002.

The Elang Kakatua development follows the last meeting of the Ministerial Council of the Australia‐Indonesia Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation, which was convened by my counterpart under the chairmanship of General Sudjana in November 1996. At that meeting we reviewed the progress made in the explor ation for and prospective development of petroleum in area A of the zone of cooperation. It was noted that cumulative exploration and related expenditure amounted to $A380 million as against a committed work program which was somewhat less.

Now, with this government in power, nearly all of area A is under active exploration. This is indicative of the petroleum industry's confidence in the exploration potential of area A and the progress being made towards the development of petroleum production within the Timor Gap.

Madam President, a total of about 15 million barrels of oil is currently forecast to be produced from the fields. That is valued at some $400 million. While not as large as the Laminaria project which is adjacent but in Australian waters, it is a significant development. The petroleum produced from this project will be subject to production sharing arrangements with the joint authority administering the zone of cooperation on behalf of Australia and Indonesia and the companies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, did you say in October 1995 that the then Prime Minister, and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . forced Mr Blount to buy his way out of the blackmail by surrendering a huge and totally unwarranted dividend payment to the government, which treats Telstra as a cash cow and not as a means of providing high quality telecommunications services to all Australians.

Minister, has your attention been drawn to an article in yesterday's Australian which reports that the Telstra board and the Department of Finance are investigating whether Telstra can afford to increase its final full dividend payment to the government? Minister, will you now rule out any increase in Telstra's dividend payment to the Commonwealth, consistent with your earlier stated beliefs, or were your statements merely opportunistic posturing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to confirm that they were not anything of the sort. In fact, I do not recall precisely what I said back in October 1995, but I can tell you roughly and, for your purposes, I think, quite suffi ciently. What Mr Keating was trying to do when he was desperately trying to plug that budget deficit gap was to insist initially that Telstra should sell off the Yellow Pages . He thought he would make the odd billion or two on the side, and that that would help him with his problem. When, of course, Telstra would not go along with that because they saw that as an integral part of their total approach, he was then very keen on breaking up various elements of the business. As we know, he confessed all on, I think, Lateline or Four Corners —one of those programs—
—Like Vision Stream.

—No, not Vision Stream. He was certainly keen on selling off Mobilenet. He would have sold off OTC, as we know, if he had had his way when the duopoly was first established. Of course, at the end of the day he was putting Mr Blount in a position where he had to make some sort of compromise offer. That resulted in a very significant dividend payment, as well as two additional early repayments of outstanding loans of, I think, $150 million each.

ANSWER.PARA: So it is quite clear that far from Mr Keating having any interest in improving the quality of telecommunication services in allowing Telstra to invest any excess proceeds, he was intent simply on taking the money from them to fix his bottom line problem.

As far as any article in the Australian is concerned, it is purely speculative. I have read it. I am not aware of any accuracy attached to it. Any decisions that are taken in relation to Telstra—the privatisation of which you opposed tooth and nail, and which of course is now subject to scoping studies and to a report from the Senate—will proceed and will be very much to the benefit of ordinary Australian consumers.

I know that on principle you lot won't want to subscribe. You are a bit like the trade union movement in Britain. Back in 1984 or 1985 when the union movement was so ideologically opposed to privatisation, they advocated to their membership that they should not participate in the share issue. Of course, the union members, having more sense than their masters, promptly went out in the face of that total boycott and subscribed to the tune of about 95 per cent and mostly doubled their money in the first month. So the workers knew what was good for them. I am sure this time around the last people they will be taking any notice of are the opposition because they know that you could not give a damn, they know that you are not really interested in anything other than pursuing your own little power games.

The fact is that the privatisation of Telstra will be very much in the best interests of all Australians. The scoping study and Finance will be making a number of decisions that will be highly beneficial in due course. They will be made in the course of the budget processes, and they will not be announced prematurely in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I again ask the minister: will he rule out any increase in Telstra's dividend payment to the Commonwealth?
—What you are really asking me to do is to—
—Is to tell the truth.

—Excuse me! Do you know what Gary Gray said last night? He said, `The people didn't believe us'. He basically said that you did not know what you stood for. In fact, he was very keen to have the party come clean. He was saying that the research of the party showed that the leadership was out of touch—`We were captives of special interests'.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. However interesting Gary Gray's comments may have been, could you ask the minister to answer what was a very direct supplementary question from Senator Bishop: will he rule out any increase in Telstra's dividend payment to the Commonwealth? That was the supplementary question he was asked, and you, Madam President, are required to direct Senator Alston to answer it. I put to you, Madam President, that comments from Gary Gray or anyone else are not relevant to this very specific supplementary question.

—Madam President, on the point of order: what I think is also highly relevant is that the de jure Leader of the Opposition actually asked the real supplementary and that was inviting me to tell the truth. I think it is highly relevant in that context to look at the credibility of the respective parties on this and other issues. I was addressing that matter, and I submit that I am entitled to do that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In answering the question, Senator, you certainly should have in mind the question that was asked, and I invite you to continue your answer.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President. Robert, you cannot keep the sabbatical going indefinitely. You have been at it now for nine or 10 months. Taxpayers are having to pay for all this. You cannot just sit by and let him wallow like this. The fact is that newspaper articles are not the basis for official government statements.
—Well, rule it out.

—We are not in the business of ruling anything in or out. They are not my decisions to take anyway. The fact is that you cannot stand the heat. What you do not like is when Gary Gray says that you ought to get out there and say you are sorry. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware of the ACTU's opposition to the government's proposal to allow low paid workers to opt out of their superannuation for equivalent cash benefits? Does the minister agree with commentators who believe that such opposition by the union movement is bizarre?
—Don't quote newspaper articles.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not go around quoting Gary Gray because it causes trouble on your side. You want to sensor him all the time. In answer to the interjection, Senator, I will not be quoting Gary Gray.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the ACTU's campaign against the government's opting‐out proposal. I must say I find it very disheartening, indeed. Yet it is all too typical that the ACTU would put its members' interests second in its desire to score cheap political points. Don't they hate it when the ACTU is attacked. This is family, isn't it? Fancy attacking the ACTU!

TALK.START.PARA: —You can attack the ACTU for three minutes without reading every word. Come on Kempy, you can do it.
—There is exactly 3½ minutes to go so just relax. This is another stark reminder of how out of touch the ACTU has become and is a good example of why it is losing members at a record rate.

ANSWER.PARA: The government announced in the 1996 budget that it was going to allow employees earning between $450 and $900 per month to negotiate the payment of additional wages and salaries in lieu of the superannuation guarantee contributions. Through this and other proposals, the government is introducing—
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There have been far too many interjections in the chamber, and answers should be heard in relative silence.
—Thank you, Madam President. I must take some responsibility for that because I did attack the ACTU. That always leads to a reaction. You say one unfavourable word about the ACTU and off they all go.

ANSWER.PARA: As I was saying—despite the interjections—under our opting‐out proposal, where an agreement has been reached between an employee and employer to pay additional wages and salary in lieu of the superannuation guarantee, the employer will be required to make the payment. This will provide low paid workers with a greater choice to either increase their superannuation savings or receive money in hand to meet current living expenses. It is one of the many measures we are introducing to reduce the inflexibility of Labor's system, especially for people on low incomes—which all of you forget about all the time. I mentioned that I was not going to quote Gary Gray, but I am going to quote Brian Toohey.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I quote Brian Toohey without it leading to loud jeers on the other side? Brian Toohey, in the Australian Financial Review of today, said:

BREAK.PARA: A union campaign against the proposal to allow low‐income earners to swap super contributions for a pay rise is bizarre . . .
Toohey had some very interesting things to say in his article. He said:

It's not often that the union movement opposes a pay rise for the poor. But this is what is happening with the ACTU's extraordinary campaign against the Howard Government's decision to let people on less than $225 a week choose a pay rise in lieu of employer contributions to a superannuation fund.
He went on to say:
In this case, old‐style "union greed" on the wages front has been well and truly supplanted by a new‐found enthusiasm for "super fund greed".
According to Mr Toohey:

Most employees whose gross pay is under $225 a week need every last cent they can lay their hands on. To its credit, the Government is offering them the chance of a pay rise without jeopardising their employment prospects. Bizarrely enough, the ACTU is insisting that its number one priority is to deny them the opportunity . . .
(Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Did you in this chamber on 12 February this year justify Telstra's press release about charging for 013 calls by saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I have seen their press releases—
the draft proposal—

is designed to be revenue neutral. Clearly they are addressing that. You even said that giving back $50 million is not enough. You acknowledge they are giving back $50 million, so why turn around and pretend that somehow this is all going to make Telstra more attractive in the float? It is sufficiently attractive already, and every Australian except your good selves will be on board.

Minister, have you discussed the benefits of the Telstra proposal with the Prime Minister? If so, why did the Prime Minister strongly rebuke you on the same day by saying, `Telstra will not be doing anything in this area that is contrary to pre-election commitments'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murphy seems to have a number of facts quite grotesquely wrong. The suggestion that somehow Mr Howard and I were at odds, let alone that somehow I was rebuked, is absolutely and totally a fabrication and distortion. In fact, can I recommend this tactic to you in future, that where you think an issue is coming up you talk to your colleagues about it beforehand and make sure that you sing the same song. That, of course, was not apparent last night when we had Gary Gray saying that leadership was about taking a position and never saying you are sorry and Mr Beazley saying, `Of course, we had to defend our record.' That is very sad. The fact is, that is a very good example of not getting your lines right.

ANSWER.PARA: What Mr Howard said in the House of Representatives on the very same day that I spoke about it in this chamber was that we would not accede to anything that was contrary to coalition policy. I think I said, `If it was clearly contrary.' There can be no doubt at all that we were singing from the same song book and it is very sad that you cannot do the same.

I suspect the real reason you are not prepared to get out there and say you are sorry—and Gray said that in the 1980s you felt very much that leadership was about taking a position and never saying you were sorry—is that you are scared witless that Paul Keating will come out to give you a very big bucket for diverging from the line. If you think that is going to get you through to the next election you are wrong. The research obviously shows Mr Gary Gray that it is about time you came clean. The fact is that Mr Beazley is not prepared to do that. I can assure you that Mr Howard and I have precisely the same attitude and we both gave the same answers in the parliament on the same day on the same issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that most Australians would think that you and Mr Howard are not singing the same tune, I ask: have you told the Prime Minister that under the Telecommunications Bill 1996 there is no legislative requirement for Telstra to provide free 013 calls? On that basis, will you tell the Prime Minister that he misled the House on 12 February 1997 or will you continue to allow him to treat you as a doormat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —If we want to talk about who is getting rolled, let us look at the Sydney Morning Herald of 20 May 1995 which talks about `The minister for getting rolled'. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: He has carriage of plenty but why do things keep going bad for John Faulkner?

It is carriage beyond the call of duty, I have to say. I do not have the slightest idea of the factual basis on which Senator Murphy suggested that Mr Howard needs a re‐education course in the provisions of the Telecommunications Act. The fact is that Telstra has not put a formal proposal to the government. The rules require that they do that and, if and when they do that, the proposal can be referred to Austel and the minister can make a decision in due course. If you have any other factual basis for suggesting that I ought to relay something to the Prime Minister, let's hear it, but you haven't trotted it out in question time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Do you agree with the recent harsh criticism of Australia's greenhouse position by a senior United States official that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . by proposing differentiation, what (Australia) is really doing is ensuring we do not reach an agreement in Kyoto.
Is your government relaxed and comfortable about accepting responsibility for derailing international efforts to address the problems of climate change?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted some comments from Eileen Claussen, I think it was, which did not surprise me because she was restating the position of her government. The position of the United States government differs from that of the Australian government on this issue, as Senator Lees knows. Our position is one that is good for the environment in terms of wanting a better international greenhouse outcome but it is also good for the Australian economy in providing extra jobs. As I have said to Senator Lees before, we do not apologise for adopting a policy that is in Australia's best interests; that is, a policy that encourages development whilst at the same time requiring high environmental standards, which includes greenhouse behaviour.

ANSWER.PARA: I take the opportunity to commend those Australian companies which have signed on to the greenhouse challenge and which voluntarily have substantially reduced their greenhouse emissions. That is a good example for other Australian companies. I am very pleased to see that program being extended now to include small business. If we work together on this issue, Australians are able to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions without the sorts of prescriptive requirements that some other countries are advocating. That is our preferred option. It is one of differentiation, which recognises the nature of different economies, and it is one we are advocating on the international arena at the moment. I am pleased that we are gradually getting some further support for it. I hope that support will continue to grow as the year progresses so that when we get to Kyoto late in the year we will get an outcome that is both fair and achievable.

TALK.START.PARA: —So, Minister, you are saying that you do not believe Australia's actions are likely to sink that agreement. Do you really believe that if we do manage to sink it that would be in our best interests? Finally, you mentioned differentiations: I note that Japan is now talking about this system. Do you support Japan's per capita emission targets—that is, the ones Japan is promoting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the senator fails to understand that what we are doing is constructively contributing to the international debate on this issue. But we are after an outcome that is fair and achievable, and I would have thought that that was sensible. Because it is sensible it is not surprising that other countries are starting to become interested in our proposal. Far from it being our intention to sink the negotiation, it is our intention to continue to constructively contri bute to it. We hope that in Kyoto we will get to a good outcome.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen an earlier submission from Japan and, whilst there are some similarities, the formula they propose is not the same as the formula that we propose. That is the purpose of negotiations that are currently taking place—to work through these various options that are on the table in order that the negotiating process might proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General. Is it a fact that Mr Costello, when shadow Attorney‐General, promised that a coalition government would not use the statute of limitations as a defence against HMAS Voyager survivors' compensation claims? At any stage prior to the last election did any coalition spokesperson contradict this commitment? Does this constitute a core or non‐core promise? Can the government's current actions over Voyager compensation be seen as a broken promise? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do not have a briefing on what Mr Costello said prior to the election or, for that matter, a briefing on the changes, to the extent there are any, subsequent to that. But I will take all of the questions you have given me on notice and I will get an answer from—
—Somebody.
—No, I will not get it just from somebody; I will get it from the Attorney‐General.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Given the allegations that Papua New Guinea has misused $30 million in funds to hire foreign mercenaries in Bougainville, will the government now lift the executive order made in 1989 by the then Attorney‐General, Lionel Bowen, permitting recruitment in Australia of mercenaries for Papua New Guinea? Is the government investigating whether Australian mercenaries were involved in recent incidents, such as the machine‐gun attack from an Iroquois helicopter on 15 January offshore at Koromira region south‐east Bougainville on three boats containing sick and injured women and children? Is the Australian government investigating weekend reports that money from the North Fly development fund is being used by the PNG government to fund mercenary activities in Bougainville? Has the Australian government or any private company or development agency ever contributed directly or indirectly to the fund?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know of any suggestion that Australians are being used as mercenaries. In fact, I thought it was illegal under Australian law. But I will check on that and see if there is any further information that we can provide. I will seek information as well on the other specific parts of the question in relation to abuse of funding from the Fly River funds.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me just reiterate that Australia obviously continues to be deeply concerned by the allegations of what is occurring in PNG. I stress `allegations' because they are of course being denied at the highest levels by the PNG government, which is still claiming that these forces are in the country for training purposes only. As we said yesterday, we regard the introduction of mercenaries within our region to be a highly unsatisfactory development in terms of our international relations, and we certainly do not see that there is any way in which mercenaries can be of any assistance whatsoever in resolving the political difficulties of Bougainville.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. The minister representing the foreign minister seems to indicate that he thought it was illegal. The exemption from the Crimes Act 1989, I believe, only makes it illegal to recruit people currently in the forces in Australia, not people who are no longer in the forces. Perhaps the minister might clarify and bring back to the Senate whether or not there will now be moves to remove that exemption, considering what is happening and the government's outrage over what is happening in Bougainville. Does this issue not highlight the hypocrisy of both the current government and the previous government in giving support for mercenaries, for the blockade of Bougainville and for our continuing military support for the Papua New Guinea defence forces despite repeated evidence of atrocities being committed by these forces on the island of Bougainville?

—We do not give support for mercenaries, and I did not realise that the previous government gave support for mercenaries. I will otherwise continue to raise the issues that you mention and see if I can get further information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Yesterday in answer to a dorothy dixer, Senator Hill, you gave an up‐beat view of the economy, particularly for small business. The latest Yellow Pages small business survey out today reports:

QUESTION.PARA: 80% of Australia's Small Business proprietors believe the Howard Government's policies are working against them or have no real impact.
And:
More than 80% of proprietors still see the Economy as being in Recession or standing still.
And:
More than 80% believe the Government does not help Small Business at all.

The survey further found that `employment growth had slowed substantially' and `despite reduced interest rates, capital expenditure has slumped'. Minister, who is correct: you or the small business community?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an example of convenient quoting: the term and the bottom line, and then ask the questions to achieve the outcome. Senator Cook could have told us that 57 per cent reported that low interest rates had either already improved their situation or they expected them to improve their situation. That is not surprising. If Senator Cook had been listening to his earphone he would know that Mr Prosser had already said in the other place that another part of the survey said that on the question of sales and profits, two‐thirds of small businesses expect increased sales in the next 12 months. So there is some good news out there, even in this survey.

BREAK.PARA: There is no doubt that lower interest rates, keeping a cap on taxes and bringing down inflation are going to benefit small business. Those things are going to give small business the opportunity to see their businesses grow and the chance to employ more Australians, and that is good for small business and good for the economy. There is no doubt that other changes that we have introduced already—changes in relation to the rollover of capital gains tax and changes in relation to the uplift factor of provisional tax—have benefited small business and will do so into the future. There is no doubt that the changes that are going to be announced in the near future, in response to the Bell task force, will be applauded by small business as well.

What you do not understand, Senator Cook, is that we are committed to small business—in contrast with your record—because we recognise that small business is the key to a growing economy and the benefits to which all Australians aspire. That is why we are committed to small business. Small business will get a fair go under us in the way that they certainly did not under you.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I never misquoted or selectively quoted. I quoted conclusions, Senator Hill. You quoted some detail which misrepresents the outcome of the survey. Is it not true that the survey found that `Nationally, small business confidence is unchanged from the low levels recorded in the August and November 1996 surveys'? The survey reports:

QUESTION.PARA: Expectations for an improved economy in 12 months time have weakened. A net 26 per cent of proprietors now expect an improved economy compared with a net 35 per cent in the previous survey.

Confidence has in fact gone down. Will the government now tell the truth, and be honest with Australians and the small business community, by admitting that business conditions are tough out there and that small business has a lack of confidence in the future? Will you live up to your much vaunted promises before the election and tell the truth, minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely. Our commitment remains to provide an economic framework within which small business can grow and employ. That is what we are all about. Part of our determination to provide that framework was demonstrated in the way in which we tackled the $10 billion deficit that we inherited, a deficit that was going to result in higher interest rates.
—You killed the domestic economy. You know that.

—You are the 20 per cent lot on interest rates. That is what you do not understand. You are the record unemployment side. We had to take the hard decisions on the economy. If you want to talk about betrayal, I remind you of what we heard on Four Corners last night, talking about your lot:

ANSWER.PARA: Workers stopped identifying with the Labor Party, and I think they did feel betrayed. I think they felt betrayed through the accord years, and a lot of criticism was levelled that way. I think they saw cuts to education and health that caused problems—
And so on. That is the real betrayal in Australian politics, Senator Cook. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, last week an historic agreement was reached by the World Trade Organisation which will liberalise the $800 billion global telecommunications market. Will the minister outline the benefits to the Australian economy, in particular for Australian consumers and the telecommunications industry, as a result of the successful outcome of these negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, it is good news for the global economy and particularly for Australia. The World Trade Organisation negotiations were all about liberalising markets, and I have to say that Australia, fortunately, has been at the forefront of trade liberalisation in this area. There are something like 68 countries, including Australia, who did make offers covering current and future market access liberalisation, and those countries represent something like 93 per cent of that $600 to $800 billion world telecommunications trade market. In fact, equipment manufacturers benefit to the tune of about $600 million a year and the total level of exports is, I think, around the $2 billion mark. So Australia is very well placed.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to the economy and small business.

I asked Senator Hill a question about small business perceptions of the economy and the fact that 80 per cent of Australia's small business proprietors believe the Howard government's policies either are working against them or have no real impact. That question arose from a survey of small business opinion published yesterday by the Yellow Pages small business index.

The minister, of course, avoided the question substantially. This government has made the primacy of small business a feature of its election promises and a feature of its economic pronouncements since the election. But there is no more eloquent a voice about the government's delivery of those promises and the government's performance on small business than that of the small business community itself.
Let me read in some detail, if I may, exactly what the press release, expressing the surveyed opinion of Australian small business, says of this government:
Eighty per cent of Australia's small business proprietors believe the Howard Government's policies are either working against them or have no real impact—
and that is according to this survey—

The survey—of 1200 small businesses across Australia, conducted earlier month—found that for the first time since the election, negative assessments of Federal policies outweighed positive assessments.
Twenty-two per cent now say that the Government's policies work against the interests of small business, compared with 20 per cent who believe them to be supportive.

Economic adviser to the Index, Dr John Marsden, said that the disenchantment stemmed, first, from the failure of economic growth and recovery to flow through to small business and, second, from the sector's frustration with perceived Federal Government inaction.
"More than 80 per cent of proprietors surveyed still see the economy as in recession or standing still and nearly 80 per cent believe the Government has not helped small business at all," he said.

Eighty per cent of small business people express a disenchantment with the government because their businesses face difficult times or their businesses are on that list giving the record level of bankruptcies in small business that have occurred in the December quarter in this nation. Small business people are not ideologically predisposed to attack the government—indeed, it is fair to say that the small business community are mostly supporters of the government—but they do so because of the economic circum stances this government has driven their businesses into and the realities they have to cope with day in and day out by the under‐performance of this government on its election promises. They do it reluctantly; but they do it because it is necessary.

The government's response here is feeble and facile. The government purports to know better than the business community does. The government has said three things in its response: first, that the quotes I gave in my question were selective. They were not. The quotes I gave were the conclusions of the survey. The answers given by the minister were selective. He quoted some balancing statistics in the detail of the survey, which are the best and most positive statistics the government could find, but they do not go to the conclusion which is damning to the government.

Secondly, the government said that things will be better in the future. Well, small business does not believe that. What small business says, overwhelmingly, is that the future for their companies will be bleaker and the future prospects will be worse. That is not a vote of confidence in the government; that is not an expression of confidence in the economy either.

Thirdly, the minister said, `Well, we cut the budget deficit last time.' That is what the government has paraded its credentials on, but that is part of the problem. Part of the problem is that they cut $274 million out of business support programs. It is no wonder small business is complaining. The government has slowed the Australian domestic economy down. Twenty‐two private sector economists surveyed in the Age estimated the economy will grow this calendar year by 3.1 per cent, which is below the level of the government forecast. We know the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself has said that the economy needs to grow at four per cent for unemployment to go down. (Time expired)

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐ members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that only one group have been excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) where such group has performed honourable overseas `active service'. That group being members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 which were excluded under `Operational Service' at Section 6. (1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

The various claims made in Statements to the House and the Senate and the contents of correspondence from various Ministers to maintain the exclusion are answered as follows, the answers are from documents obtained under FIO and from public record:

(i) `They were never allotted for operational service', (contained in a letter from the Hon. Con Sciacca Minister for Defence Science and Person nel 1995). A letter from the Secretary Department of the Navy to Treasury dated 11 November 1955 stated `the date that the Navy were allotted for operational service was 1 July 1955'.

(ii) `Members of the RAN were only doing the duty for which they had enlisted', (October 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). This applies to all Service personnel everywhere.

(iii) `They were in no danger', (November 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). They shared the same danger as all other Australian Service personnel serving in Malaya at the time.

(iv) `They were not on Special Overseas Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel to Mrs Williams of Adelaide dated October 1996). Requirement for Special Overseas Service was introduced in 1962 without retrospective conditions, therefore has no relevance to events of 1960.

(v) `They were not on Active Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel dated October 1996). It is now, as it was then, that Service Personnel had to comply with one of three requirements for Active Service, this group complied with two, or twice as many as is needed. The one that they did not comply with was, `is in military occupation of a foreign country'.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate should remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act, thereby giving the Australian sailors involved comparative recognition with the Army and RAAF personnel that served at the same time, and all other Australians who have served their Country on active service overseas.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:

(1) That members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 have been deliberately and wrongly excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable overseas `active service' under `Operational Service' at Section 6.(1)(c)(ii) of the Act. They are the only Australian Citizens to be treated in that way.

(2) A defined group of citizens, who served in the Malaya area, being members of the Royal Australian Navy Defence Forces so affected, have been wrongly excluded, whereas members of the Army and Air Force were not so excluded, and this is supported by documents in the Australian Archives and elsewhere on public record.

(3) Allied veterans of 50 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Korean War can have had qualifying eligibility for benefits under the Act. Veterans of South Vietnam, the Philippines, South Korea, Thailand and the United States can have eligibility resulting from the Vietnam War. Their service was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded.
(4) It is claimed that:

(a) Members of the RAN were designated as `on active service' when they served in a designated zone that is within a 12 NM limit offshore from the coastline of Malaya from 9th May 1952 to 1st December 1960. These dates are verified in Declarations by the Governor‐General, Commander‐in‐Chief of the Naval and Military Forces of the Commonwealth, contained in Commonwealth Government Gazettes No. 40, 5th June, 1952 and No. 82, 8th December, 1960.
(b) Members of the RAN were engaged on operational duties that applied to all service personnel everywhere.

(c) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, including the death by `friendly fire' of a sailor during support operations. This can be attested to be a Naval Flag Officer who witnessed the death on board his ship.

(d) The Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this authorisation was contained in Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy.

(e) They were not bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements which were introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962, which act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended.

(f) the Australian citizens serving in the Royal Australian Navy complied with all the requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

(g) The Department of Veterans' Affairs has indicated it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In Parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not be found. This action would not have been taken had the Parliament been properly informed. Parliament has unfortunately approved the introduction of qualified retrospectivity through accepting these amendments to the Act resulting in an injustice being perpetrated against ex‐service personnel.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray

Your Honourable House take appropriate action to remove the previous Government's discriminatory exclusion of Naval personnel in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of Australian citizens' honourable service with the Royal Australian Navy for their country, whilst on `active service' in the Malaya campaign.

Not only is Senator Vanstone's incompetence and maladministration of her portfolio there for all to see, but you would really have to question the judgment of Mr Howard, the Australian Prime Minister, as a result of his recent actions in reinforcing the behaviour of this minister.

In support of this urgency motion, let us look at Senator Vanstone's record. Major foul‐up No. 1 was that as soon as Senator Vanstone came into office she refused to set targets to deal with unemployment. BREAK.PARA: Even in early February this year on the Meet the Press program she could not tell Michelle Grattan what a `significant' drop in unemployment meant. She was not willing to put her money where her mouth was. But that was not enough; there was major foul‐up No. 2 from Senator Vanstone, which really landed Mr Howard a political time bomb. That was her statement that a government that failed to get unemployment down did not deserve to be re‐elected—Senator Vanstone's own words, which will be hung around her neck I can assure you of that. What a political liability to her own party she is.

Then there was foul‐up No. 3 by Senator Vanstone. That happened when she decided that she would take a different approach to her parliamentary responsibilities in terms of her accountability to the parliament. She said to the opposition in May that `the reason you will not have some information is that we will not give it to you if we do not want to'. No minister can get away with that. She had to be disciplined by her own leader and she has been on a comparatively short leash in question time, trying to improve her behaviour. Then there was major foul‐up No. 4. Literally within weeks of attaining office she achieved what I thought was the absolutely unachievable by creating a very angry coalition of vice‐chancellors, university staff and students—virtually everyone in the higher education sector—who were absolutely outraged at her unguarded mumblings about a 12 per cent cut in university funding. It was the Prime Minister who again had to come in and try to sort out the mess that this incompetent minister had created.

Then there was major foul‐up No. 5 by Senator Vanstone. That was when the HECS fees went up. Science enrolments dropped across the clever country and you had a situation where Senator Vanstone blamed the universities, science minister McGauran blamed the schools, but neither of them blamed themselves or their own government which had been absolutely responsible for this appalling policy lapse.

Then there was major foul‐up No. 6 when Senator Vanstone went forth into the ERC to discuss the budget as minister, not with any eye to the social repercussions of the policy she was proposing. She savaged her department to the tune of a $1.8 billion cut leading to the destruction of labour market programs such as skillshare and other mechanisms that had been put in to ameliorate long‐term unemployment and youth unemployment.

Then there was major foul‐up No. 7. On top of her efforts in relation to slashing labour market programs in this country were cuts of nearly $2 billion to the higher education sector, including the planned academic salary rises. This was a savage blow to the university system. What did she describe them as? I recall it was as `a mere nick'. What was the result—absolute pandemonium throughout the higher education sector in Australia.

Then, straight away, she moved up to her very memorable major foul‐up No. 8. That was one of her most infamous achievements in her time as a portfolio minister. That was the invention of the fictitious Wright family. This minister allowed a story to go uncorrected—front page of the Daily Telegraph. In the estimates committee hearing last year she told me that she thought it was far more important to tell Senator Tierney, who is here in the chamber, and her ERC colleagues the truth about the fraudulent Wright family, as opposed to telling the public. It is the public who were misled by Senator Vanstone on the Wright family. She thought, `I will not bother about correcting the record and telling the public the truth.' She did not worry about the readership of the Daily Telegraph, she did not tell the battlers—or, as John Howard now refers to them, the mob. No, she did not correct the record. I recall that the Sydney Morning Herald as far back as 18 October last year in an editorial headlined `Not Wright' said:
Mr Howard is wrong to be tolerant about (Senator Vanstone's) performance. Ministerial heads have rolled for less than Senator Vanstone's folly.

What did she do in this? As she has done on so many occasions when she has been caught out by the opposition, she blamed her department. She blamed the officers of her department. That is her stock‐in‐trade.

Of course, she would not take the advice of her departmental secretary in his suggestions about how to respond to the Wright family allegations, would not take the suggestion to tell the public the truth at the earliest possible opportunity. And shortly after Senator Vanstone's extraordinary performance on this matter when explaining her handling of the Wright family matter, her departmental secretary, Mr Hollway, resigned. I suspect that Mr Hollway saw the writing on the wall in relation to Senator Vanstone.

Then there was major foul‐up No. 9. Senator Vanstone misled the Senate over projections for unemployment reductions when she claimed that the Labor government did not have departmental advice that a five per cent unemployment rate could be achieved.
Then there was major foul‐up No. 10 from Senator Vanstone. She misled the Senate over the level of university fees charged in overseas institutions.

Then there major foul‐up No. 11 from Senator Vanstone when she even misled the Senate over the Democrats' Internet mail—you would recall this, Senator Stott Despoja—during some half‐smart dorothy dix answer in the Senate. She could not even get that right—another own goal from this incompetent minister.

Then there was foul‐up No. 12 from Senator Vanstone, which goes to her own office administration. Even in day‐to‐day responsibilities, Senator Vanstone cannot get it right. Look at the summary of questions on notice that have just been put out by the Senate Table Office. Senator Ian Macdonald—a coalition senator—on 7 May asked a question on new work opportunities. How long did it take to get an answer out of Senator Vanstone and her office? It took 225 days to get an answer to one of her own colleagues. For a question on the activity test that Senator Woodley asked it took 204 days to get an answer. Most ministers, even in this government, can do a lot better than that. It is just not acceptable to take well over half a year to get these sorts of answers out of a minister and her office.

Then there was major foul‐up No. 13—unlucky 13. The latest blunder was to allow genuine complaints about the Austudy actual means test to persist for two months, do nothing about it, and then announce the changes when young people have decided to quit university because they cannot afford to go and when she had caused genuine heartache among poorer families that were caught out by her botched performance, her botched administration. As in the Wright family matter, she blamed the department. That is her stock‐in‐trade: blame the department for the mess over the means test and not accept that the buck stops with her. It is no wonder that this minister has caused the public outrage that she has. It is no wonder that even the most reasonable people in the community are calling for her to be sacked. TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat amazed by that which I have heard of Senator Faulkner's contribution. He obviously has not got too much to do today other than sit around and see if he can drum up 13 complaints.
—It wasn't hard.

—Senator Collins indicates that it was not hard. I do not think she finds much hard. She is usually most satisfied with whatever effort she puts in—one of the most self‐satisfied senators we have here. I doubt she finds any task difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, I think we have been stretching the bounds of reality somewhat with some of the suggestions put forward by Senator Faulkner who, if he does not want to listen, is welcome to leave the chamber or sit in his seat. It is not in accordance with standing orders, Mr Deputy President, to simply wander around the place as if it is a cow paddock that you have got lost in.

I take just one example. It is apparently a bureaucratic bungle that the coalition has steadfastly refused to set targets for unemployment. Where is the bungle in that? We just have a different view about what the appropriate way is to handle policy. And what is the appropriate way to respond to that sort of questioning? The previous government used to set targets and, if they did not achieve them, they had some reason why they did not; if they did, then they were self‐satisfied.

This government would not be happy to set an unemployment rate target and then, if we achieved it, to say, `Oh well, there are no problems. We have achieved our target. We will forget about the people who are still unemployed.' How ludicrous is that? And if members opposite want to look at what their current leader, their leader for the moment, Mr Beazley, has to say about setting targets, they will see that he in fact agrees.

Senator Faulkner seems to think that to say that the electorate will be very upset if they cannot see some progress on unemployment is a mistake. I cannot see any mistake in that. I think the electorate elected us because they want to see some progress made in eating into the ingrained stain on the economy, unemployment, that members opposite left. They just waltzed out of 13 years of government leaving high unemployment, and now they are annoyed because we say that the electorate is going to continue to be annoyed unless something is done about this. So I cannot see that that is a problem.

Thirdly, Senator Faulkner comes in with one of his examples of what he calls incompetence, quoting me as saying, `We won't give them information if we don't want to'—which, of course, was the practice followed by the previous government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said it.

—Senator Sherry interjected that that was what I said. By omission he misleads in the same way that Senator Faulkner does. He may know full well the next sentence in that comment, which is, `We will, within the bounds of propriety, be far more accountable to parliament than you ever were.'
—Why did you say that?

—I did say that at exactly the same time. I said, `We will be more accountable to parliament than you ever were,' but does that stop senators opposite touting around the place, tittle‐tattling about with lies and deception? No, they have got nothing else to do. They have been drinking vinegar lately. The taste of opposition is fairly bitter, I know. I experienced a number of years of it, but I never reduced myself to that sort of twisted bitterness that I see from those on the other side. Yes, I did say, `You won't get information if we don't want to give it to you,' but I did add the rider which anyone who has experienced opposition would add; that is, that we will be more accountable to parliament than the people on the opposite side of the chamber ever were.

SPEECH.PARA: Fourthly, I apparently upset the vice-chancellors. They were upset—I admit that—to be told that there was a big black hole left by Mr Beazley and that we had to make a contribution to it. For some reason they were upset at the suggestion that, as some of the leading educationalists in Australia, they should have a chance to shape that savings proposal, otherwise it would be shaped by people in Treasury and Finance. It seemed to me to be a sensible proposition to be up front and direct—as is my wont—and say, `Look, there is no messing about here; you are not going to be saved from this. We are going to have to make a contribution. Why don't we sit down together and figure out how to do that?'

The vice‐chancellors, much to my regret and displeasure, said, `Finding savings is dirty work. Putting the budget back into the black is dirty work. We just want money. We never want to be cut. We never want to know anything about that.' Of course, only 25 per cent of Australian school leavers get the opportunity to go into university. The remaining 75 per cent either go and get a job or do some TAFE training; they are very interested in the budget getting back into the black and in being able to get a job because the government can keep its act together.

As for HECS and science enrolments falling, again Senator Faulkner either cannot be bothered getting the facts right, or is just too damn lazy to look them up, or is intellectually incapable of doing so—I do not know which. When I last commented on this I indicated that the final enrolment figures at that time were not known to me, and I do not think they were known to anybody else. The figures for applications were known to me. I made the point that the number of science applications had fallen. It had fallen for a number of years. And—surprise, surprise—I indicated that one of the reasons it had fallen was that not enough kids were doing year 12 science; science in year 12 was falling off. That is something that the state education departments might like to look at.

If universities want to attract people to science, they might look at what they are offering. Universities are going to have to become more market orientated to the students, looking at what students want. I do not want universities ever to become businesses, but I do want them to be more business like.

Senator Faulkner said that there had been a savaging of labour market programs. In its last year in government Labor wasted about $780 million on its three least effective programs, with outcomes of about 30 per cent. So if I am going to go to the Australian public, I am certainly not going to say, `Listen, we have been tipping 70 per cent of this money down the drain. Would you like us to keep doing it?' Of course you wouldn't do that. How ridiculous is that?

Senator Faulkner again misleads and deceives in his contribution to the chamber by saying that there had been $2 billion of cuts to higher education. What a load of codswallop and rubbish. I know full well what the reduction in finance to universities is; it is one per cent against their forward estimates. It is not one per cent against last year's figures, but one per cent against what they were thinking they were going to get. They are getting more this year than they got last year. Where the government has made savings is by asking students who get the private benefit of going to university to make a higher contribution. We have made substantial savings there, but let's us not pretend that we have made substantial $2 billion cuts to universities, because that is an outright lie.

The savings with respect to universities I still describe as nix; after all, we have given them a one per cent cut against their forward estimates and allowed them to drop postgraduate student load. The dollars per student are roughly the same. The quality of higher education would stay the same if it were related only to dollars, but will improve because of other changes we have made.

As for the Wright family—I have said this time and time again, but Senator Faulkner shuts his ears; he does not want to listen—I do not believe that I did mislead the public about that. When you mislead the public you intentionally go out and tell them an untruth. I did not do that. It has been made abundantly clear that I was led to believe that the Wright family was an actual family. But what was untrue about that? Simply that it wasn't an actual family. The rest of the story is true: that families like that, without the presence of an actual means test—that is, with simple income and assets tests—can access social security. The message there is true. The only difference is that if I had said, `This is a construct of a family that could get social security without an actual means test,' there would be no fuss. Instead of saying that it was a construct of a family, I said that it was an actual family, because I was led to believe that it was an actual family. If that is a mortal sin, I should be dead by now.

Senator Faulkner went on and claimed that there has been some misleading about projections of what the previous government was told. He knows full well, as he was at the estimates hearings, that there was a mistake in an article in the paper. As often happens with some journalists, they quote each other. It is like a talkfest. One person tells someone and they tell someone else, and all of a sudden 50 people know the same thing. It came from one article that was not sourced to me. Someone decided to paraphrase—with no bad faith, I think; nonetheless they paraphrased wrongly—and gave an incorrect impression. There are a couple of other things he mentioned, but I want to come to the Austudy matter.

There has been an administrative bungle in the department, and I have admitted to that. I think the Mercury described it as `an unprecedented apology'. I noticed that last night on Four Corners, Gary Gray, the national secretary of the Labor Party, took the opportunity to say that in the past they thought leadership was about taking a position and never saying you were wrong. At least we have had the guts to do what Gary Gray says you should have done; that is, that if you had said you were sorry and acknowledged where you had got things wrong, then the result in March last year might have been different—and you never said you were sorry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say you were sorry?

—You can look at the quotes of what was said. I unreservedly apologised for what had happened. You have never done that. Your government has never apologised for the mess that you created. More importantly, before you were on to this, I fixed the mess. It's been fixed! (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are supporting the motion before the chamber today. We have repeatedly expressed our concerns about the performance of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) in this portfolio, but our concern today is as much with the policies of this government in relation to employment, education, training and youth affairs and that economic rationalist agenda that is pursued by this government inasmuch as it is with the performance of the minister herself. To that end, I will be moving an amendment to the motion before us today in which I choose to specify the administration, or maladministration, in the areas of higher education reforms and Austudy specifically.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth starting with the most recent example, the one that has been discussed and debated in this chamber over the last few days in relation to the actual means test. One point should be made very clear—that is, there is a parliamentary secretary who has responsibility for Austudy and that is Mr Tony Abbott, who is in the other place. He seems to have played a very minimal role in this whole saga apart from a very fleeting and contrived performance on the 7.30 Report when they investigated this issue. So I suspect that that parliamentary secretary has done little to assist matters and perhaps should share in some of the blame that the minister is experiencing.

The administration of the actual means test has been incompetent, it has been maladministered, from the choice of the ABS figures that were used in the imputation right through to the design of the Austudy application form. I again ask the minister and her colleagues: why were the ABS figures chosen? Is it not the case that they—that is, the department and the minister herself—were advised that the ABS figures were inappropriate, were too harsh and should never ever have been used for the purposes of imputation?

We are seeing students being judged on their anticipated earnings as opposed to their taxable income. It is outrageous. It is no wonder that it resulted in such chaos and maladministration. But, added to that, we saw the maladministration of the hotline. There were departmental officials being cut as a result of budget changes and a hotline was established. We knew that 90,000 students at least would be affected by the changes to Austudy in the budget and yet something like 15 people were staffing a national hotline for a few hours per day.

As for the minister's claim in this place recently that she acted swiftly, again, the Democrats strongly disagree with that. We argue that, if the minister wanted to act swiftly, she should have done so in the first round of enrolments, not the third round. Action should have been taken as early as January considering this issue was debated and brought to the attention of the minister and departmental officials as early as November estimates last year and in departmental briefings with my office in December last year. So these problems were not rectified swiftly.

Some 90,000 people were expected to be affected by the budget changes—$60 million. This is a mean‐spirited government that will do anything to pursue its economic rationalist agenda, even if it means cutting off 90,000 students—and, of course, other Austudy changes in the budget included increasing the age at which students were eligible for the independent rate from 22 years to 25 years.

The Democrats still call on the minister and, again, we argue that this is an incompetent and maladministered move. We argue very strongly that the guidelines—or, specifically, the chapter regarding the actual means test guidelines—should be made public. They have yet to be made so. We would call on the minister to do that, just as we call on the minister to reconvene the Austudy references committee to review the guidelines and stick to a pre-election promise that her predecessor, Senator Robert Hill, made—that is, that the actual means test guidelines would be reviewed. Senator Hill promised to do that, and we call on the government to do so.

Of course, the manufactured—or constructed, as the minister calls it—Wright family is another example of, yes, the Senate being misled. The minister may argue it was unwitting, but in fact it was not only the Senate but also the public who were misled. The really appalling fact about that whole Wright family saga was not that a couple of kids, a Pajero or a swimming pool were added, but that it in fact perpetuated the negative and regressive notion that people are out there ripping off the system, that somehow there are all these millionaires rorting the system. In actual fact, as we all know, a majority of people who do receive Austudy benefits—and they are hard enough to get—are living at 35 per cent of the poverty line levels. It is an outrage that Austudy benefits are so hard to access for many families and, in particular, for those who are below the age of 25 and those from regional and rural families. That was the greatest offence with the Wright family saga.

I turn quickly to the higher education reforms. Last year this Senate passed the most radical and regressive changes ever to higher education. The minister is guilty, yes, of implementing fees and charges in a regime that now means your ability to study is determined by your ability to pay. That is through the implementation of up-front fees. We have just seen Melbourne University come up with a benchmark of $110,000 for dentistry. I am sure the poor kids of Australia and the battlers, who have been referred to so many times in this place by the government, are going to be accessing dentistry courses at that price!

Again, the former government is culpable as well in this matter. While I appreciate that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) moved this motion today, the maladministration of higher education in this country was certainly begun by the former government, which began and helped entrench a system of user pays education.

As for the vice-chancellors being a little upset, they were ropable, and with good reason. Not only were they scared by the idea of a 12 per cent cut across the board, but they have endured a $1.8 billion cut. Their operating grants have been slashed directly contrary to a pre-election promise. This government promised to leave Austudy as it was, to not cut operating grants and to strengthen regional and remote universities. What has happened? We have seen campuses close. The St George campus at UNSW, which Senator Tierney has repeatedly referred to in this place, is closed.

As for lower enrolments, of course applications are down all across this country, specifically in areas such as science. Yes, we have seen the tail wagging and tail chasing. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) argues it is the schools and the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) argues that it is universities—the point being that these are the very areas on which this nation's future prosperity and training in employment rely. Yet science courses, business courses, Aboriginal and Islander courses, education courses and nursing courses have all suffered with reduced enrolments, not to mention specifically mature age student enrolments, which have experienced a decline.

The minister referred to students and their representative organisations squealing like stuck pigs and academics living in ivory towers. She has urged academics to dob in their colleagues with notes in brown paper bags. This is all offensive and incompetent behaviour. It is behaviour to which the Democrats have strongly objected.

In relation to labour market programs, I share some of the concerns that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate has put forward today. I want stress that at least 107,000 places have been lost in the area of labour market programs. They have not been compensated for by the introduction of a so-called token green corps, which will provide something like 240 places in the 1996-97 financial year and less than 4,000 places over the next three years.
