SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In respect of this matter, I ask once again for Senator Campbell to reconsider the position he has taken. Senator Brown has raised a valid point—that is, the Hansard is the document to which people look to find the debates of the parliament. An important part of those debates is of course a second reading speech. A second reading speech is a speech—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell interjecting—
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Campbell and Senator Faulkner, I am trying to listen to what Senator Bolkus is saying.
—I gave Senator Bolkus leave—not you, Senator Faulkner.
—Senator Campbell, can we please have some order. I call Senator Bolkus.

—The second reading speech is a speech which explains the bill. It basically explains at length the reasons for the bill and it puts flesh to the structure of the legislation. As such, it has an important role in the judicial process and an important role for people who want to know what the legislation stands for. For ordinary Australian citizens—whether they are private citizens or part of the business community or other pressure groups in our society—the second reading speech explains to them the government's policy, the government's motivation and the broad structure of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reading speech is a very essential and fundamental aid to interpretation, not just by the courts but by the broader com munity. As such, the speech should appear on the public record of the parliament and, of course, Hansard is a public record. So it is important in terms of people and groups knowing what the bills are about.

As I said earlier, the second reading speech is also an important aid in legislative interpretation. As such, it finds recognition in the Acts Interpretation Act. Second reading speeches have often been used by the courts to give meaning to words in the legislation which otherwise may be nebulous or unclear.

It is important to stress the point that Senator Brown made—that is, all these second reading speeches are of little use to people if they are not readily accessible, and the most accessible way for people is their appearance in the Hansard of the parliament. If the speeches are not there, people have to go through another process to try to find them and ascertain what the legislation is about. If they are in the Hansard, then that is readily accessible.

The Hansard is documentation which, for instance, is available on the Internet. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There are courtesies in the Senate in relation to the granting of leave, and they are courtesies that the opposition takes very seriously. We have had a situation in the last half hour where an urgency motion has been debated by the Senate. I sought leave on behalf of the opposition, having heard speeches from Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Harradine, to amend a motion standing in my name to include words that had been moved by Senator Stott Despoja. We had the extraordinary situation where the courtesies of this place were—
—Withdrawn.

If that is the way the government intends to do business, this place just will not work. I do not think we have faced that situation of a failure to grant leave—until now, with Senator O'Chee behaving in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: I do accept that you have to make a political assessment of issues relating to the granting of leave. For example, I noted in question time today that leave was refused on two occasions when Senator Bob Collins sought leave to table a document. According to the government, leave was refused on the basis of the normal courtesies of the place. For those who are unfortunate enough to be listening to this debate at the moment, let me explain what those courtesies are. If a senator wishes to table a document or have a document incorporated in Hansard, traditionally he or she would have to show that document to the opposing political party. In the case of an opposition senator, he or she would show the document to the government; in the case of a government senator, to the opposition.

The point was made by government senators during question time that Senator Collins had not shown that document to the government. It is a point that can be accepted, and in the cut and thrust of debate, particularly at question time, we did not hear the opposition take that issue any further.

But this place simply will not work if we have a situation where we do not get a modicum of cooperation from the government. The government may feel that at the moment it effectively has a working majority in the Senate. It may feel very confident about its capacity to stitch together a majority of votes on any issue that comes before the chamber. But the standing orders of the Senate are such that there is always a capacity for senators to use them to ensure that the government has grave difficulty in dealing with its legislative program.

I, better than most in this place, do have an understanding of that. As Manager of Government Business in the Senate for a number of years, I had to deal with a most uncooperative and unreasonable opposition, the now coalition government. I had to deal with filibustering on numerous occasions. It was difficult for the then government, which commanded only a minority of senators, to see its legislative program advance.

As a result of the last election, we now have an opposition which actually understands the need for progress to be made in a legislative program and understands, because of its recent experience in government, that the procedures of this place have to work not only in the interests of oppositions but also in the interests of government. The approach of this opposition is very different from the approach of the coalition when it was in opposition for 13 years. Any serious alternative government will always give a lot of consideration to these sorts of issues. But there is also a responsibility by governments and office holders of political parties to ensure the good operation of this chamber.

We have seen an example this afternoon of a very inexperienced whip in Senator O'Chee, someone who has demonstrated by his incapacity at times even to attend divisions, his lack of understanding of the workings of this place. I was very disappointed not so much in Senator O'Chee but in Senator Brownhill, who as the responsible parliamentary secretary in the chamber did not override Senator O'Chee's boisterous call to refuse leave to my perfectly reasonable proposition.

This is something that the government needs to take account of. Often the new government comes into the chamber and thanks the opposition for its cooperation—often privately it thanks the opposition for its cooperation. But the government ought to realise that this has to be a two‐way street. There also is a need for the government to take seriously its responsibilities for the proper processes and courtesies of this place to ensure that this chamber actually works.

BREAK.PARA: It is very easy for a government or an opposition—frankly, for any individual senator who is so minded—to up‐end good order and good process in a chamber like the Senate, where still no one political party has a majority. I hope this is a lesson that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Campbell), who is listening to this contribution by leave, will take on board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am listening without leave and you are speaking.

—My contribution is by leave, Senator Campbell. I hope that you will indicate to Senator O'Chee what his responsibilities are in this regard. Frankly, if the government determines to not grant leave to opposition senators who are opposing courses of action which are in the best interests of this place—in the interests of progress being made with our routine of business and the good order of our proceedings—then we have a major problem. That is not the way that we do business. It has not been the way we have done business in the past.

BREAK.PARA: I hope that senior government ministers and those with ultimate responsibility for government business in this place—that is, the Manager of Government Business—will take serious account of this, will take Senator O'Chee aside, will counsel him and will indicate to Senator O'Chee that if he is going to be absolutely unreasonable in his approach to the workings of this chamber the opposition will not be minded to bend over backwards to give the level of cooperation that you have seen.

It is a two‐way street. I actually think many in the government understand that that is the case. I believe that Senator Campbell, since he has embraced his new responsibilities as Manager of Government Business, has worked hard in trying to ensure that the Senate's business moves along. I accept that Senator Campbell does understand these things. It might be time, Senator Campbell, for you to communicate that to other office holders in this place.

Senator O'Chee's behaviour in the urgency motion before the chamber was absolutely unacceptable. We will not be tolerating any repeat of it. I ask you to exercise some responsibility in this regard because, if Senator O'Chee intends in the future to refuse leave when properly asked for by the opposition—or any other senator in the chamber for that matter—to see matters progress quickly and in a proper fashion, inevitably there will be consequences. You cannot expect the opposition to be the only political party in this chamber to be accepting its responsibilities. Government has some responsibility, too, and I think you should think about that very carefully.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1996
This bill establishes the core elements of a new telecommunications regulatory framework for the era beginning 1 July 1997.

Together with related bills in this package, it will introduce full and open competition, reinforce and reinvigorate consumer protection arrangements and bring about significant reforms to technical regulation.

It will provide an environment in which Australian businesses and telecommunications users will get maximum value from a dynamic telecommunications industry. The regime will provide a framework within which the Australian telecommunications sector can develop into an industry based on:
world class infrastructure using the latest market driven technology mix;
a multitude of service providers offering diverse and innovative carriage and content services; and
contestable market strategies which drive prices down and quality of service up.
The legislative package fulfils in full the Government's election commitment to bring about a new era of competition and to establish a world class consumer protection framework.

Telecommunications services are an essential component of our lives, both at home and at work. The role they play is becoming increasingly important as technological developments not only provide innovations in traditional telephony services, but allow us to reach out to the world via services such as the Internet and to access financial, education, health and similar services. We are beginning to see the benefits that telecommunications services present when used as a tool in these ways. The future can only be more exciting.

Technological developments are also presenting significant opportunities for the industry itself. In the year to June 1996 gross product in the communications sector increased by over 12 percent—an annual growth rate significantly higher than the economy generally. Australia is not alone in witnessing rapid growth in communications industries. Market expansion overseas, and particularly in our region, present new opportunities for export enhancement.

To enable this country to take full advantage of the social and economic opportunities presented by these developments, we must have a telecommunications industry which is constantly challenged to innovate in order to develop new services, increase quality and reduce prices.

The Telecommunications Act 1991 enabled the introduction of limited infrastructure competition and full resale of telecommunications services. Australian consumers have witnessed significant gains from these developments, however, they were only ever intended to be transitional arrangements in a decade‐long process that has been progressing in steps towards full and open competition. The package introduced here will achieve that long‐term objective.

Facilitating the development of a truly competitive market from a monopoly is an evolutionary process. The Government must progressively remove regulatory barriers and constraints on genuine competitive conduct: it also must increasingly shift responsibility for regulation to the industry itself. Significant efficiency gains can be achieved through greater reliance on self‐regulation in networked industries such as telecommunications because regulatory structures and arrangements can be better designed to reflect industry and community needs.

This package of legislation provides the framework for the telecommunications industry to take responsibility for key areas of regulation over and above the legislative guarantees provided. In the areas of competition regulation, mechanisms are available for the industry to develop agreed approaches to access and pre‐selection management for adoption by the regulator. Similarly, in addition to foundation consumer protections and technical standards, the industry will have all the tools necessary to develop codes of conduct in consumer‐related areas and voluntary technical standards.

The successful development of industry codes will be to the benefit of all players. It is therefore incumbent on all in the industry to fully and constructively participate in these self‐regulatory mechanisms. The industry itself must provide the necessary resources. Consumer representatives must, where appropriate, have the opportunity to contribute to issues. In this context, I welcome the preparatory work the industry has undertaken in recent times, including work associated with the formation of the Telecommunications Access Forum and an overarching industry forum known as the Communications Industry Forum, to establish self‐regulatory and consultative mechanisms in anticipation of its future responsibilities.

Self‐regulation will evolve over time—it should not be expected to be comprehensive from day one. It requires progressive review and strengthening of self‐regulatory mechanisms which, in turn, will require industry commitment on an ongoing basis.

The Government recognises, however, that in some areas industry consensus may not be achievable, and safeguard provisions exist to enable the regulator to step in and establish standards or arbitrate an outcome.

This bill is the core of a package of bills which comprise the post‐1997 telecommunications legislation. The Telecommunications Bill 1996 will replace the Telecommunications Act 1991 (which is repealed by the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996). Other key bills in this package include the Trade Practices Amendment (Telecommunications) Bill 1996, which sets out the primary industry‐specific competition policy arrangements, and the Australian Communications Authority Bill 1996, which establishes the new telecommunications and radiocommunications regulator, the Australian Communications Authority. Arrangements for moving to the post 1997 environment are contained in the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996.
I now turn to the major provisions of this bill.
The Telecommunications Bill 1996, in broad policy terms:
establishes the fundamental regulatory arrangements for industry participants—carriers and service providers;

re‐enacts and reinvigorates legislative assurances in regard to community obligations and consumer protection including the universal service obligation, the continued provision of the option of untimed local calls, the customer service guarantee, privacy provisions, law enforcement and defence obligations and the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman;
provides the framework for increased industry self‐regulation through codes of practice;

entrenches in legislation rights and obligations in regard to key competition issues such as pre‐selection, facilities and network information access rights for carriers and the oversight of the international activities of industry operators;
incorporates reformed technical regulation provisions with an emphasis on industry self‐regulation; and

establishes the Australian Communications Authority's functions and powers with regard to the regulatory environment and specific powers for the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to undertake public inquiries into—and enforce obligations relating to—telecommunications issues for which it is responsible.
The bill also contains the Government's proposed provisions relating to carrier powers and immunities post 1997.
There will be no regulatory barriers to entry into the telecommunications industry.

For regulatory purposes, the bill separately identifies persons who are responsible for regulatory obligations relating to telecommunications network infrastructure—carriers—and those persons who provide carriage or content services to the public by using this infrastructure—service providers.
In most cases, carriers will be the owners of network infrastructure.

Carriers are very important to the regulatory scheme because they provide the basic transmission infrastructure on which the supply of carriage and content services to the public rely. Carriers will be individually licensed and subject to charges that recover the costs of regulating the industry. They will also share the net losses incurred in fulfilling the universal service obligation. Any artificial arrangements designed to thwart these policy intentions will be met by swift action by the Government.

Infrastructure providers must have the flexibility to meet the demands of the Australian community by whatever technology they consider most appropri ate. The Government is therefore removing the current regulatory distinction between carriers on the basis of the technology they use. Licensing requirements will not be used to place regulatory barriers on the choices carriers make in regard to delivery technology. In addition, the access arrangements included in the Trade Practices Amendment (Telecommunications) Bill 1996 will mean that judgements by new and existing operators about whether to build their own networks will need to be made against the option of buying capacity off other carriers on reasonable terms and conditions.
The Government will be maximising the opportunities for Australian industry through a licence condition that requires all carriers to have an industry development plan, unless exempted.
This arrangement extends the previous regime which has resulted in substantial benefits to the Australian industry, the carriers and the economy as a whole.
A carrier's industry development plan would also be expected to include research and development activities that the carrier undertakes for people with a disability.

A number of provisions provide that carriers will not be required to publish information about their plans that may be commercial‐in‐confidence, however, the Government does not intend that these provisions be used as a means of denying useful information to the industry and the public.

The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has announced details of a monitoring body to monitor and report on progress with implementation of industry plans. He has also announced that the Government will treat sales to carriers as if they are sales to Government for post 1997 industry development purposes. These policies will support the industry development licence condition.

The bill makes use of a new concept of service provider which includes both carriage service providers (who supply carriage services to the public) and content service providers (such as the providers of broadcasting and on‐line services). Carriers will be service providers when they provide carriage or content services.

Service providers will be regulated by rules established in the legislation, replacing the existing class licence regime. The Government does not intend that the bill be used to regulate the content of content services: content service providers have been included so they can benefit from rights to access services under the proposed access regime. Content will continue to be regulated under legislation such as the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.

Telecommunications services are today a fundamental part of social interaction, particularly for those in remote communities. They also provide a lifeline in emergency situations and are an essential component of business activities. While competition is itself a vital part of the Government's strategy to encourage continuing improvements in service and price reductions, the Government recognises that market forces may not always be sufficient to guarantee outcomes that are in the interests of all consumers.

While this bill re‐enacts many aspects of the consumer protection and community obligation arrangements in the existing Telecommunications Act, in doing so the Government has taken the opportunity to fundamentally reinvigorate those existing arrangements. We have also incorporated additional new protections applicable for an open entry market.
At the core of the community obligations of the telecommunications industry is the universal service obligation (USO).

The Government is firmly committed to maintaining a general obligation on the industry to ensure that all people in Australia have reasonable access to the standard telephone service (including customer equipment), payphones, and prescribed additional carriage services on an equitable basis, wherever they reside or carry on business—and a supporting obligation to supply those services on request. The universal service provisions in this bill, while based on those in the Telecommunications Act 1991, incorporate changes to clarify and update the universal service obligation (USO), improve efficiency and transparency, and align it with the open market post‐1997 regime.

The "standard telephone service" is a carriage service for voice telephony (or for a person with a disability, an equivalent service required to be supplied to comply with the Disability Discrimination Act 1992) which enables end‐users supplied with the service to ordinarily communicate with other end‐users supplied with the service.

The Government is considering the options for upgrading the actual services to be supplied under the USO after receiving the recommendations of Standard Telephone Service Review Group. The legislative arrangements in the bill will, however, enable ongoing review and enhancement of the standard telephone service and the universal service obligations generally.

The USO provisions presented here will provide for greater clarity about the manner in which universal service providers intend complying with their obligations and establish clear accountability mechanisms for evaluating their performance. This will be achieved through a requirement that universal service providers submit plans on how they will progressively fulfil the USO, with approved plans being publicly available.

Given the potential for carriers other than Telstra (which will continue to be subject to price cap arrangements under the Telstra Corporation Act 1991) to become a universal service provider, a provision has been included to enable the regulation of charges for services supplied under the USO, thereby safeguarding the continuing affordability of such services. The bill also provides increased flexibility for the Government to ensure the net cost of the universal service obligation reflects efficient practices, including through use of selection processes such as tendering.

Carriers will contribute to funding of losses incurred in fulfilling the USO in direct proportion to their share of total "eligible revenue", which is to be defined in regulations, but would include revenue from a broad range of carriage services. Alternative arrangements will enable carrier contributions to be set according to a methodology determined by the Minister, with the agreement of carriers.
During the election campaign the Government promised that the option of untimed local calls would be maintained and extended to business customers. This bill fulfils that commitment.
This bill will also:
provide a Customer Service Guarantee (CSG) covering all carriage service providers in relation to the connection of standard services, rectification of faults and keeping of appointments;

extend the existing obligation to enter into the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman scheme from just carriers to all carriage service providers providing the standard telephone service to residential and small business customers, or a public mobile telecommunications service, and to other carriage service providers directed by the ACA to join the scheme;

require carriage service providers who were not carriers on 30 June 1997, to comply with a scheme formulated by the ACA to offer protection to residential customers supplied with the standard telephone service against a failure to supply the service when the customer has made a protected payment;

provide that end‐users of a standard telephone service have direct access, free of charge, to emergency services, in accordance with requirements imposed by the ACA on carriers, carriage service providers and emergency call persons (the objective here is to provide, from the perspective of the end‐user, a single emergency service that meets the community's needs, while providing necessary flexibility to address changing arrangements and technologies);
re‐enact obligations on telecommunications operators to co‐operate with law enforcement agencies; and
protect the confidentiality of communications and the personal particulars of customers from unlawful disclosure by persons in the telecommunications industry.
A codes of practice regime is established to provide a framework for industry self‐regulation by means of industry‐developed codes that are registered with the ACA.

The codes regime will supplement and enhance the fundamental consumer protection arrangements established in this bill and to which I have already referred. Codes can address areas of concern to consumers that are currently unregulated. As a failsafe, this self‐regulation mechanism is backed up by the ability of the ACA to make mandatory standards.
The bill contains a list of examples of areas which might be dealt with in codes and standards.

The Government has placed certain limitations on the matters which a registered code or standard may address, including restrictions on dealing with the content of content services or requiring networks to have certain design features or performance requirements (except in relation to billing, quality of service or other prescribed matters). This is to avoid duplication of regulation and unwarranted restrictions on commercial activities.

Codes and standards must reflect the legitimate needs and interests of all industry stakeholders if they are to work properly. Consultation will occur with the industry, the public and the TIO and, where privacy issues arise, the Privacy Commissioner, in the development of registered codes and the making of standards.

The period for public consultation must be a minimum of 30 days, although the actual period will be a matter of judgement by the ACA or the industry section in developing the code. It is expected that the ACA or the industry section will provide a longer period for public consultation where the issues are complex, but in doing so will need to have regard to the urgency of the need for the code or standard.
Existing standards established under the Telecommunications Act 1991 will continue under transitional legislation until replaced by a code or standard.

While Part 10 of the bill requires the TIO scheme to provide for the investigation of complaints relating to carriers and carriage service providers, this is not meant to imply that other sections of the telecommunications industry would be prevented from joining the TIO scheme, or that these other sections of the industry may not establish alternative bodies to perform ombudsman functions in relation to codes or standards. Such options would be compatible with the Government's policy that telecommunications be regulated in a manner that promotes the greatest practicable use of industry self‐regulation.

In Better Communications , the Coalition gave a commitment that from 1 July 1997 it would eliminate the current exemptions for telecommunications carriers from planning and environmental laws. The provisions in this bill fulfil that commitment.
The provisions establish a general rule that, from 1 July 1997, State and Territory planning and environment laws will generally apply to telecommunications.

There are three exceptions to this general rule: first, some standing exemptions for installation of low impact facilities and temporary defence facilities, and for inspection of land and maintenance of facilities; second, a limited case‐by‐case appeals process; and third, a continuation of some specific powers and immunities currently contained in the Telecommunications Act 1991 including to allow for all facilities legally installed under that regime to continue to be exempt from State and Territory laws and to allow individual subscribers to be connected to networks existing as at 30 June 1997.

The case‐by‐case appeals process would be to an independent panel. An appeal will only be open to carriers in limited circumstances: where negotiations with the relevant authorities or owners have broken down; the facility is an important part of a network of national significance; the construction of a substantial part of that network has been approved by relevant authorities or already installed; and the advantages to the national economy from the operation of the network to which the facility belongs outweighs any associated degradation of environmental amenity.

The panel will comprise the Chairman of the ACA and up to four specially appointed associate members. In appointing those members, the Government will make sure that they are independent, have appropriate experience and the ability to consider all appeals in an impartial manner.
The Government is very conscious of the public concern about possible degradation of environmental amenity due to installation of aerial cable and construction of mobile towers.
The bill requires that carriers co‐locate mobile facilities on radiocommunications towers and radiocommunications sites—and facilities in ducts—unless it is not technically feasible to do so.

Equally importantly, cabling of the broadband type will not be permitted to be located aerially, unless the relevant State or Territory Authority agrees. Connections of individual subscribers to these existing types of networks will be required to be underground unless the subscriber agrees to aerial connection.

The Government's pre‐election commitment to subject the telecommunications industry to State and Territory planning and environmental law from July 1997 is reinforced by our intention to have only limited transitional arrangements. These arrangements will apply to carrier activities which have been through notification processes and where construction has commenced before 30 June 1997. In relation to broadband aerial cabling, construction must be completed by 30 September 1997 and construction of other types of telecommunications infrastructure must be completed before 31 December 1997.

The bill continues and reinforces the provisions in the 1991 act which prevent the law of a State or Territory from operating so as to discriminate against a carrier or a class of carrier. It provides that a State or Territory law has no effect to the extent that it discriminates, or has the effect of discriminating, either directly or indirectly against a carrier or a user or potential user of a carrier's services. An example of one kind of discrimination that this provision deals with are State or Territory laws which give special powers or immunities to public utilities such as electricity suppliers or railways where these are not also given to any carrier in that State or Territory in like circumstances.

The Government's policy in relation to carrier powers and immunities from 1 July 1997 strikes the right balance between encouraging investment in infrastructure to meet the growing demand for new telecommunications services and facilitating further competition while also addressing the legitimate concerns of local communities about the effect of the rollout of telecommunications infrastructure in their local environment.

The primary basis of competition regulation in this package of industry‐specific legislation is contained in the Trade Practices Amendment (Telecommunications) Bill 1996. However, a number of obligations are imposed under this bill to promote fair, but vigorous, competition in this industry.
Existing pre‐selection rights will be extended to all carriage service providers supplying the standard telephone service with additional mechanisms for extension to other services.
Carrier licence conditions will establish obligations in regard to providing access by other carriers to certain facilities and network information.

Certain powers are also re‐enacted to prevent, mitigate or remedy conduct contrary to Australia's national interest, engaged in by international telecommunications operators in their dealings with carriers and carriage service providers in Australia.
This bill also provides for the phase out of the existing AMPS network by the year 2000.

Technical regulation arrangements for the telecommunications industry will be significantly reformed by this bill, with greater emphasis placed on industry self‐regulation underpinned by standards made by the ACA for issues where self‐regulation is inappropriate.
The ACA will be able to make standards for customer equipment and cabling used in conjunction with carriers' networks and facilities for the purposes of:
protecting the integrity of telecommunications networks;
protecting the health or safety of persons affected by the operation of a telecommunications network or facility;
ensuring that emergency service numbers can be called; and
ensuring interoperability for customer equipment used in conjunction with the standard telephone service.

The ACA will be able to make standards covering additional features for standard issue customer equipment used for a standard telephone service to meet the needs of people with a disability. Compliance with such a standard will be taken into account in actions under the Disability Discrimination Act 1992.

The Government expects that there will be adequate opportunity provided for consultation with consumer representatives on technical regulation standards by industry and/or the ACA when standards are being developed.

The management of telecommunications numbering will be the responsibility of the ACA. The ACA numbering plan may include rules about number portability where the ACCC forms the opinion that portability for particular numbers will promote the long‐term interests of end‐users.
The ACA and ACCC will have reserve powers to address problems which may arise in the increasingly important area of electronic addressing.
The bill will also re‐enact and update:
regulatory powers to undertake inquiries, undertake investigations, and to enforce obligations imposed under the bill; and
obligations on the ACA to report to the Minister in regard to carrier and service provider quality of service and compliance of operators with the USO and codes of practice arrangements.

The measures contained in this package will require the ACCC to undertake various activities during 1996/97 involving additional expenditure in the order of $1m. Additional expenditure will be offset by carrier licence application charges and annual fees imposed by the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Termination Bill 1996 and the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Charges) Bill 1996. The details of the ongoing resource requirements for the ACA and ACCC will be considered in the 1997/98 and subsequent budget processes.

This bill places increased emphasis on the use of industry self‐regulation, particularly in technical regulation and codes of practice. It is expected that some costs will be incurred by industry in establishing self‐regulatory processes. Those costs, however, should be outweighed by efficiency benefits for the industry as an outcome of establishing self‐regulatory approaches which reflect industry needs and broader community benefits from codes of practice.

The introduction of competition under the current Telecommunications Act has brought with it financial benefits for both residential and business consumers through lower prices. Product innovation and increased quality of service, arising out of new competition, have also contributed benefits to the business community and therefore the competitiveness of the economy as a whole.

This bill will facilitate an enhanced level of competition in telecommunications, increasing further the pressure on existing and new market operators to achieve greater levels of efficiency and quality, and to pass those benefits on to consumers.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the Senate.
TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (TELECOMMUNICATIONS) BILL 1996

This bill is a critical component of the package of legislation introduced to establish a new regulatory framework that will provide for a more competitive telecommunications industry from 1 July 1997.

The bill contains key competition‐related provisions that complement the broader regulatory arrangements, including in relation to consumer protection, contained in the Telecommunications Bill 1996. It will bring the regulation of competition in the telecommunications industry more closely into line with general trade practices law and incorporate telecommunications industry‐specific rules on competition into the Trade Practices Act 1974 (TPA). The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) will be responsible for administering these rules.

The post‐1997 telecommunications legislative package will remove regulatory barriers to market entry, as well as a number of artificial regulatory distinctions, such as between mobile and fixed services. The reforms within this package will give all industry operators, both existing and new, the freedom to pursue the business strategy they choose.

In an open market, all carriers and service providers, including Telstra, must be given the flexibility to engage in normal competitive conduct—Australian consumers will not benefit from regulation that unnecessarily hampers the ability of operators to respond to the market. Therefore, the approach adopted in this bill is not as interventionist as the anti‐discrimination prohibitions in the Telecommunications Act 1991.

That said, there remain good reasons for there to continue to be industry‐specific competition regulation for telecommunications. The removal of regulatory barriers to entry does not automatically result in the appearance of normal competitive market structures.

Telstra continues to wield significant market power derived primarily from its historical monopoly position. There is also scope for incumbent operators generally to engage in anti‐competitive conduct because competitors in downstream markets depend on access to the carriage services controlled by them. The possibility, for example, of incumbents engaging in anti‐competitive cross‐subsidy practices could threaten the further development of a competitive environment.

All members of the telecommunications industry will be fully subject to general trade practices law contained in Part IV of the Trade Practices Act. The exemption from Part IV given to carriers under the Telecommunications Act 1991 for the supply of basic carriage services will not be continued.

Total reliance on Part IV of the TPA to constrain anti‐competitive conduct might, in some cases, prove ineffective given the still developing state of competition in the telecommunications industry. The fast pace of change and complex nature of horizontal and vertical arrangements of firms operating in this industry mean that any anti‐competitive behaviour could cause rapid damage to the competition that has already developed and severely hamper new entry.

Therefore, as well as Part IV of the act applying fully to telecommunications, the amendments made by this bill will supplement Part IV by increasing the ability of the ACCC to respond swiftly where anti‐competitive conduct is evident.

Another important feature of the telecommunications industry is that competitors inevitably must make use of each others' networks. This is because many communications services (for example, telephone calls) require `any‐to‐any' connectivity—the ability for any end‐user of the service to contact any other end‐user, regardless of who the suppliers are or on what network they are connected. This `any‐to‐any' feature—and the Government's commitment to promote the diversity of carriage and content services available to end users—requires an access regime that includes additional features to those contained in the general access regime in Part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act.
Furthermore, the Government recognises that there are expectations of continuity regarding the broad rights contained in existing access arrangements in Part 8 of the Telecommunications Act 1991.

For these reasons, the Government's philosophy in preparing the telecommunications access regime has been to follow an approach based on Part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act as far as practicable, but nevertheless to introduce some additional refinements to ensure that the arrangements will work effectively for the telecommunications industry.

A smooth introduction of the new access regime depends critically on transitional arrangements. Transitional arrangements contained in the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 will essentially retain existing access rights for carriers, extend those rights to service providers and fulfil the Government's election commitment to achieve open access in regard to the carriage of broadcasting services over cable networks.
I will now turn to the key provisions of this bill in more detail.

This bill inserts a new Part XIB into the Trade Practices Act establishing a number of additional powers for the ACCC to deal with anti‐competitive conduct in telecommunications markets and to collect information to assist it in monitoring competition in the telecommunications industry.
This Part establishes a `competition rule' that a carrier or carriage service provider must not engage in anti‐competitive conduct. Conduct is considered to be anti‐competitive in two circumstances.

The first circumstance relies on an effects‐based test, in recognition that damage can be inflicted on competition regardless of the purpose motivating that behaviour. In an industry where competition is in many areas still in its developmental stages, requiring proof of purpose may unduly delay regulatory action to stop anti‐competitive conduct.
The second circumstance is where a carrier or carriage service provider is in contravention of certain provisions of Part IV of the Trade Practices Act (sections 45, 45B, 46, 47 and 48).

Anti‐competitive conduct as defined in Part XIB is in wider terms than under existing Part IV provisions. The possibility of pecuniary penalties and private rights to seek injunctions in regard to conduct or claim damages is therefore limited to conduct in relation to which the ACCC has taken specific action.

The ACCC will be able to bring proceedings before the Federal Court at any time for an injunction to stop anti‐competitive conduct, but will also be able to issue a competition notice stating that a carrier or carriage service provider has engaged in anti‐competitive conduct.
While a competition notice remains in force:

the ACCC will be able to bring proceedings before the Federal Court for substantial pecuniary penalties in relation to further conduct of the kind detailed in the notice (the Court may also make ancillary orders, including orders requiring the disclosure of information, and/or the publication of advertisements); and

other persons will be able to seek an injunction to restrain or otherwise deal with further conduct of the kind detailed in the notice or, if they suffer loss or damage as a result of any further conduct, to take action to recover the amount of the loss or damage.
A competition notice will also be prima facie evidence of the matters in the notice for the purpose of any proceeding taken in relation to the notice.

As the new legislative arrangements will introduce some level of uncertainty until regulators and the industry develop a clear understanding of its operation, the ACCC will be required to formulate guidelines before 1 July 1997 for use in deciding whether to issue a competition notice. Furthermore, a carrier or carriage service provider proposing to engage in a course of conduct will be able to seek an order from the ACCC to have that conduct exempted from the scope of the competition rule because it will result in a net benefit to the public or where the ACCC is satisfied that the conduct is not anti‐competitive conduct.
The ACCC will need strong information‐gathering powers to enable it to effectively administer competition regulation in the telecommunications industry.

Its power to direct carriers and carriage service providers with a substantial degree of power in a telecommunications market to file tariff information will allow the ACCC to examine carrier and carriage service provider conduct in telecommunications markets, including where it has concerns about potential anti‐competitive conduct but an insufficient basis on which to decide whether to take action under the competition notice provisions. Particular items of information submitted under a tariff filing direction would be publicly released where this would have a net public benefit.
The ACCC will also be empowered to make record‐keeping rules with which specified carriers and carriage service providers will be required to comply.

The Government does not want to see its policy of establishing a fully competitive telecommunications industry thwarted because of lack of, or the existence of inappropriate, regulatory requirements. Accordingly, the ACCC will be required to review and report annually on competitive safeguards within the telecommunications industry.

It is intended that competition rules for telecommunications will eventually be aligned, to the fullest extent practicable, with general trade practices law. The legislation provides that a review of the operation of these arrangements be undertaken before 1 July 2000. In conducting this review, consideration will be given to whether any or all of the provisions of Part XIB should be repealed or amended.

The telecommunications access regime in Part XIC provides foundation access rights to all industry operators and establishes a framework within which the industry can develop additional arrangements to improve the efficiency with which access is supplied.

There is no logic in retaining blanket distinctions between the access rights of carriers and service providers in a market with open entry. It is likely that some future service provider operations will dwarf niche market carriers and legitimately require access at levels equal to that provided to large carriers.

The access regime provides for regulated access rights to be established for specific carriage services and related services, and provides a framework within which the terms and conditions of access can be determined. It will reduce the power of those owning or controlling important infrastructure or services which are necessary for competitive services to be supplied to end‐users. In doing so, judgments by new and existing operators about whether to build their own networks or buy capacity on existing networks will be driven by normal commercial factors—decisions to build will only be taken where commercial considerations clearly favour this strategy. The regime will therefore promote the efficient use of and investment in infrastructure.

It is a clear policy intention that, as much as possible, both the determination of access rights and terms and conditions of access be the result of commercial processes and industry self‐regulation. The bill provides for the establishment of a Telecommunications Access Forum (TAF), a body open to all carriers and carriage service providers, to manage those matters. The Government expects the industry as a whole to work constructively to develop industry‐driven solutions to access issues which reflect the legitimate interests of those seeking access and those under access obligations, and which operate in the long‐term interests of end‐users of telecommunications services.

The Government wants the benefits of increased competition to flow as soon as possible. It wants all service providers to be placed in the position of having foundation access rights equal to those currently enjoyed by the carriers. Transitional arrangements included in the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 will provide that services supplied between the existing carriers will, unless they would not promote the objects of the access regime, be declared services under this new access regime. In addition, the ACCC is required to declare a carriage service to bring within this access regime the supply of broadcasting services over cable networks. This fulfils our election commitment to remove the exemption of pay television carriage from the access regime given by the previous Government.

The Government does not intend to allow any industry participants to avoid legitimate access requirements through artificial arrangements. Furthermore, service providers now have the ability to control services to which regulated access is appropriate and this will increase in the future. Therefore, the declaration of a service would create access obligations regardless of who the supplier is. At the request of an access seeker, an access provider must supply the declared service, interconnection and associated services, unless complying with the request would prevent the provider meeting the reasonable requirements of existing users.

At the same time, the Government recognises that exemptions from some or all of the standard access obligations for particular access providers or classes of access providers may be desirable. A provision allows the ACCC to give such exemptions where it would promote the long‐term interests of end‐users.

Access providers must comply with their access obligations on terms and conditions which may be determined in three alternative ways: as commercially agreed by the access provider and access seeker; as detailed in an access undertaking; or as determined by the ACCC through arbitration.
Commercial negotiations are a matter for the parties and, in the absence of a dispute, the regime does not interfere with these processes.

The Government will be encouraging the TAF to develop an access code setting out model terms and conditions for complying with the standard access obligations which are capable of being voluntarily adopted in an undertaking. This access code mechanism provides the industry with a very valuable tool to achieve efficiencies in the manner in which access is provided where general agreement can be reached. The Government expects that the code development work will initially focus on traditional telephony services and, over time, broaden to address other services. The Government expects that there will be little need for the ACCC to use its safeguard power to determine a code because the industry itself will develop satisfactory model terms and conditions.

The Government will also be encouraging the larger access providers to submit an access undertaking for ACCC acceptance. This would both improve the certainty surrounding the terms and conditions on which those persons must comply with the access obligations and provide increased certainty for access seekers.

Access undertakings, which would determine the terms and conditions of access to which the undertaking relates, may either adopt model terms and conditions in an access code, or seek to establish specific terms and conditions. Public consultation is an important requirement before an industry access code can be approved or an undertaking that does not adopt the code can be accepted.

If an access undertaking does not address a matter about access and commercial negotiation processes have failed, either party to the negotiations may notify the ACCC that a dispute exists and seek a determination on the matter. Arbitration processes broadly reflect the parallel provisions contained in Part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act. These provisions would not, however, prevent the industry itself establishing its own arbitration arrangements, but provides a bedrock right of ACCC arbitration to all parties should it be necessary.

To meet concerns about a party to a dispute failing to negotiate in good faith, the bill gives the ACCC the power to give procedural directions to the party to facilitate a resumption of those negotiations.

In an industry where there are often substantial differences between the market power of an access seeker and access provider, concluding commercial negotiations will often be difficult. The access regime provides the necessary tools for the industry itself to develop broad solutions to access issues, but also, where necessary, for the regulator to intervene. However, if parties to negotiations are broadly aware of the outcome the regulatory regime may impose, they are more likely to be capable of reaching agreement independently. Therefore, there is scope for broad guidance to be provided by the regulator and Government in order to facilitate commercial processes.

Access pricing issues is one area where disputes may often arise. Accordingly, Part XIC will enable the Minister to make a determination regarding the principles to be applied in determining price‐related terms and conditions. Access undertakings, access codes and determinations made under the arbitration provisions must be consistent with any such determination.

While the power to determine pricing principles will provide a useful mechanism to give guidance to the industry, the preferred approach is to rely, as far as possible, on the broader regulatory regime and ongoing guidance from the ACCC as the regulator. The Government will monitor the implementation of the regime in determining whether to exercise this power.

In conclusion, the provisions in Part XIB and Part XIC will assist in creating more vigorous competition at all levels of the telecommunications market with benefits to the Australian community through lower prices and better quality. The new industry‐specific competition provisions contained in this bill will serve to reduce damage that can be inflicted by those wielding general or localised market power. They will also open up opportunities for industry participants to offer new and innovative services to consumers.
Together with the provisions contained in other bills in this package, this bill will bring long‐term rewards to all users of telecommunications services.

This bill is part of a package of bills, including the Telecommunications Bill 1996 and the Trade Practices Amendment (Telecommunications) Bill 1996, that comprise the post‐1997 telecommunications legislation.
The bill establishes the Australian Communications Authority (to be known as the ACA) as the regulator for the new telecommunications regulatory framework from 1 July 1997.

The ACA will be formed by merging AUSTEL, without its competition regulation function, with the Spectrum Management Agency. The administration of competition regulation will be transferred to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

The ACA's major functions will be the regulation of telecommunications in accordance with the proposed Telecommunications Act 1996 and the regulation of radiocommunications in accordance with the Radiocommunications Act 1992. This will see the ACA being responsible for many consumer matters, technical regulation and the management of the radiofrequency spectrum.

An important consideration for the ACA will be the Government's underlying preference for industry‐self regulation and the ACA's proposed role in assisting industry to establish self‐regulatory arrangements and providing a safety net if self‐regulation fails.

The bill sets out the ACA's functions in addition to those set out in the proposed Telecommunications Act 1996 and the Radiocommunications Act 1992. These include: reporting to and advising the Minister in relation to the telecommunications industry and the radiocommunications community and in relation to matters affecting consumers; managing Australia's input into the setting of international standards; and provision of information and advice to the public.

This will ensure that the ACA uses it powers consistently with overarching Government policy. For example, the making of technical standards would be expected to be consistent with the relevant Council of Australian Governments' guidelines.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS (UNIVERSAL SERVICE LEVY) BILL 1996

This bill imposes a levy on telecommunications carriers with a view to funding losses incurred by universal service providers in fulfilling the Universal Service Obligation (USO) under the proposed Telecommunications Act 1996. The USO is defined in clause 144 of the Telecommunications Bill. This bill is therefore an integral part of the legislative machinery for ensuring all people in Australia, regardless of where they reside or carry or business, have reasonable access, on an equitable basis, to standard telecommunications services and payphones.

The details of the USO arrangements are contained in Part 7 of the proposed Telecommunications Act 1996. Briefly, that Part sets out the methods for calculating universal service carriers' net universal service costs incurred in fulfilling their USOs and for calculating participating carriers' contributions to these costs on the basis of their shares of total eligible revenue. Levy is only payable when a carrier's contribution exceeds the net costs it has itself incurred as a universal service provider.

This bill imposes levy on a participating carrier to the extent that, in a financial year, its contribution exceeds the amount of its own universal service costs. This excess is known as its levy debit balance. The amount of the levy is equal to the levy debit balance.
Part 7 of the proposed Telecommunications Act 1996 provides for the calculation of the universal service levy.

The levy is designed to recover from carriers the losses that result from supplying loss‐making services in the course of fulfilling the USO. The total net cost of supplying those services will depend on all carriers with a USO identifying loss‐making areas and the extent of losses in those areas. Total losses may vary from year to year according to a range of factors including demand, new investment, traffic levels, changes to the definition of the USO and the cost of capital.

The relative contributions of participating carriers will depend on the total net universal service cost and each carrier's share of total eligible revenue. The share provides the basis on which total costs are apportioned to each carrier. Thus a carrier earning 50 per cent of total eligible revenue would be liable to fund 50 per cent of the total net universal service cost. Deducted from a carrier's total contribution (known as its "levy debit") are the amounts it has already expended in fulfilling its USO. The actual levy imposed on, and payable by, a carrier is therefore the amount by which the carrier's contribution exceeds what it has already expended as a universal service carrier (ie. its "levy debit balance"). Where a universal service carrier's expenditure in fulfilling the USO exceeds its contribution requirement, it has a levy credit balance and is entitled to receive a payment from the levy that is collected.

Given the number of variables that are involved, both in terms of universal service costs and carrier revenue shares, the amounts that will be payable under the levy cannot be quantified. Historical figures give some idea of the costs that have been involved in the past. The total net universal service cost was $235m for 1994‐95.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS (NUMBERING CHARGES) BILL 1996
This bill provides for the imposition of charges in relation to certain numbers allocated to carriage service providers.

The bill is consistent with the Government's pre‐election commitment to collect charges from the sale of reserved number ranges and to review the process for the allocation of numbers to service providers with a view to improving efficiency.

Telephone numbers are currently allocated by AUSTEL free of charge to carriers and service providers who may charge for these numbers. A price‐based allocation system for these numbers, as proposed by the Telecommunications Bill 1996, can be used to remove the current windfall gains and encourage an efficient allocation of this resource.
The bill provides for two types of allocation charge.

If a number is allocated to a carriage service provider in accordance with a price‐based allocation system determined by the ACA under the proposed Telecommunications Act 1996, charges will be imposed on the allocation of the number to the provider and will be payable by the provider. The amount of charge imposed will be the amount determined by reference to the results of a tender process, public auction or some other process carried out as provided by the allocation system.

If a number is allocated to a carriage service provider otherwise than in accordance with a price‐based allocation system, charges (ascertained in accordance with a disallowable determination made by the ACA) will be imposed on the allocation of the number to the provider. This amount will be up to $100,000 per number and will be payable by the provider. The ACA will, however, be able to exempt a specified number or a specified class of numbers from charge.

With respect to the 1997/98 financial year, and subsequent financial years, the bill will impose the annual numbering charge on carriage service providers who hold an allocated number. This charge will be ascertained in accordance with a disallowable determination made by the ACA. This amount will be up to $100,000 per number and will be payable by the carriage service provider who holds the number. The ACA will, however, be able to exempt a specified number or a specified class of numbers from charges.

As ACA determinations setting allocation and annual numbering charges will be disallowable instruments, Parliament will be afforded an opportunity to review these determinations. As a further limit on the ACA's ability to set numbering charges, the Minister will have the power under the Australian Communications Authority Bill 1996 to direct the ACA to set allocation charges (other than those imposed in accordance with a price‐based allocation system) and annual charges for numbers at a particular level. The Minister will also have the ability to direct the ACA not to impose numbering charges for particular numbers such as numbers used for the standard telephone service or numbers which have a high public value, such as emergency `000' and `110/119' community service numbers.

. `13' six digit and `13 4' eight digit numbers used for special network services
. `1800' ten digit numbers reserved for freephone services
. `190' ten digit information services numbers

TELECOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996
This bill is part of the package of bills that comprise the post‐1997 telecommunications legislation.

This bill makes arrangements to facilitate the transition from the current regulatory regime to the post‐1997 regime. It provides necessary support to the Telecommunications Bill 1996 and the Trade Practices Amendment (Telecommunications) Bill 1996.
The bill contains transitional provisions and consequential amendments to other acts related to the proposed Telecommunications Act 1996 dealing with matters that include:
the merger of the Australian Telecommunications Authority (AUSTEL) and the Spectrum Management Agency (the SMA) to form the Australian Communications Authority (to be known as the ACA);
the transfer of competition policy resources from AUSTEL to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (the ACCC) on 1 July 1997;
. the telecommunications access regime;
. carrier licences;
. technical standards;
. indicative performance standards;
. the universal service regime;
. the chart of accounts and cost allocation manual;
. international aspects of carriers' activities;
. cabling and customer equipment;
. protection of the confidentiality of communications;
. reviews and reports about the telecommunications industry;
. anti‐competitive conduct in the telecommunications industry;
. the numbering plan;
. the exercise of powers by AUSTEL before 1 July 1997;
. interception capabilities; and
. tariffs for the supply of carriage services.

The proposed transitional arrangements are aimed at preventing a hiatus when the post‐1997 telecommunications regime commences by continuing, where appropriate, existing regulatory instruments into the new regime. These regulatory instruments may be only partly relevant in some instances and will need to be reviewed either before or after the commencement date.

The arrangements also permit necessary action to occur before 1 July 1997 so that the benefits of the new regulatory regime flow from the earliest possible date. This is particularly important to achieving a fully functional access regime on 1 July 1997.
The consequential amendment made to section 600F of the Corporations Law has been approved by the Ministerial Council for Corporations.
I now turn to the key provisions in the bill.

The merger provisions provide for the necessary transfer of assets and liabilities to the ACA and ACCC and, more importantly, that any proceedings, investigations, public inquiries, Ombudsman investigations and advisory committees will continue after 1 July 1997. The ACA will be required to review the current advisory committees of AUSTEL and the SMA to assess their continuing relevance and role in the new regime.

Fully effective access and interconnection arrangements are critical to achieving a competitive telecommunications industry. The complex nature of such arrangements means that preparatory work must commence on access issues as early as possible, to ensure a smooth transition into the new access regime. In concert with the commencement of the Trade Practices Amendment (Telecommunications) Bill 1996 at Royal Assent, this bill provides a legislative basis for that work to commence.

Transitional arrangements included in this bill will establish, on day one of the new regime, access rights broadly equivalent to those which existing carriers enjoy. In addition, these provisions give effect to our election commitment to bring within the access regime the carriage of subscription television services over broadband cable networks. Consultative requirements will ensure the initial list of declared services for the purposes of access reflects the long‐term interests of end‐users.
The bill also enables consultative work on a telecommunications access code to begin before the commencement of this legislative package and for this work to be recognised under the legislation.
The continuity of existing carrier‐to‐carrier access agreements is also assured during this critical period.

Persons holding carrier licences under the Telecommunications Act 1991 as at 4 June 1997 will be deemed to have been granted a carrier licence under the proposed Telecommunications Act 1996 on 1 July 1997. From 5 to 30 June 1997 inclusive, the Minister will be able to make, vary or revoke carrier licence conditions generally or in relation to each specific carrier licence.

Any technical standard about network matters that is in force on 30 June 1997 will have effect from 1 July 1997 as if it were an industry standard determined by the ACA under the new Telecommunications Act. Technical standards for customer equipment will transit to the new regime provided they are consistent with the new act.

Ministerial determinations, declarations or directions under the Telecommunications Act 1991 about: the universal service obligation to supply, install and maintain payphones at specified locations in Australia; the national universal service carrier; and about net cost areas will continue to apply after 1 July 1997 with appropriate changes in terminology. Arrangements are established for carrying forward the universal service fund and levy.

A notification or direction about the international aspects of carriers' activities given under the current act that is in force on 30 June 1997 will continue to apply to an existing carrier that is a Signatory to INTELSAT or Inmarsat after 1 July 1997.

The Radiocommunications Act 1992 is amended to account for the proposed merger of the SMA with AUSTEL and the proposed consolidation of the general powers and functions of the ACA in the Australian Communications Authority Bill 1996. There are also changes to the technical regulation provisions to harmonise them with those in the Telecommunications Bill 1996.

The transition to the post‐1997 regime and its initial implementation will require considerable effort by the ACA, the ACCC, AUSTEL, the SMA and the Department of Communications and the Arts. The ACCC is expected to receive supplementary funding in the order of $1m for the necessary pre‐commencement tasks it needs to undertake and this will be recovered from carrier licence fees in 1997/98. RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1996

The Radiocommunications Amendment Bill 1996 seeks to amend the Radiocommunications Act 1992 to facilitate increased competition in telecommunications and deals with a number of other matters to improve mechanisms for the management of the radiofrequency spectrum. The Radiocommunications Act 1992 provides for this management which includes: planning the use of the spectrum; allocating and issuing licences; making technical standards; and enforcing compliance with the act and subordinate legislation.

The use of radiocommunications‐based technologies to deliver communications services is increasing. Timely access to radiofrequency spectrum is essential for the rapid development of competition in telecommunications, with flow‐on benefits for the Australian economy and consumers. The development of further competition in telecommunications is the principal objective of the post 1997 telecommunications regulatory reforms. The amendments proposed in the bill complement amendments proposed in related telecommunications legislation.

Madam President, in essence, the amendments provide for: sale of spectrum while encumbered and later clearance of incumbent users; application of section 50 and other related sections of the Trade Practices Act 1974 to the allocation and issuing of radiocommunications licences; a Ministerial power to limit the amount of spectrum persons can acquire at price‐based allocations; extending the period of spectrum licences to a maximum of fifteen years; implementation of electromagnetic compatibility requirements; the setting of radiocommunications standards for health and safety purposes; and the removal of provisions for technical licence specifications.
I now turn to the details of the bill.

Current legislative arrangements require that before a radiofrequency band is re‐allocated to apparatus or spectrum licences for new uses, the band must be cleared of all incumbents or, in the case of spectrum licences, the apparatus licences must be converted to spectrum licences by a difficult process that could result in the spectrum being unsuitable for some purposes. This can defeat the purpose of re‐allocating spectrum for efficient and beneficial uses. The clearance‐then‐sale process takes an extended period of time—up to 10 years in some cases—and can leave spectrum under‐utilised for many years. It can also lead to unnecessary, costly clearance of spectrum if the allocation process shows demand for access to the cleared band is less than anticipated.

Even when spectrum has been allocated, there could be a period when it is not fully used, for example, while equipment is ordered, delivered and installed or while the demand for the services grows to the extent that all the spectrum is required.

Selling spectrum while encumbered will allow early allocation to the new owner, who can undertake planning while the rights of the incumbents are protected. Under the proposed system of re‐allocation declarations, incumbents receive at least two years notice of the need to vacate spectrum. The actual period will depend on the circumstances, including the extent of any previous forewarning of incumbents by planning processes and the urgency of the need for the spectrum for new uses. Incumbents will also have the opportunity to buy at auction the spectrum they are operating in.

After the clearance date, incumbents can also remain if commercial terms are agreed with the new owner. Some incumbents may be able to continue operating their transmitters and receivers without any changes. Others may need to make some changes, however, they may not need to re‐site or substantially alter equipment. For example, they could be in a position to make frequency adjustments to their equipment to continue operation in other bands or in the same band but in a position that is more convenient for the holder of the new licence. All in all, the proposed amendments will offer incumbents a range of options for continuing access to radiofrequency spectrum while making the spectrum available for new uses in a timely manner.

Under current arrangements, spectrum licences may be issued for fixed terms up to ten years. This term is proposed to be extended to a maximum of fifteen years to provide greater certainty and opportunity for return on investment.

A ten year spectrum licence term was not considered by industry to be long enough to offer an attractive investment. A licence term of up to fifteen years should enhance potential participants' confidence to commit to substantial financial investment in communications infrastructure.
The Trade Practices Act 1974 (TPA) currently applies to radiocommunications licences after they are issued, but not to the initial allocation and licence issue.

The proposed amendment would apply section 50 of the TPA to the licence issue process and to the use of spectrum under an authorisation given by a licensee to third parties. This closes gaps in regulatory coverage.

The amendment proposing the creation of a Ministerial power to set limits which would apply during a licence allocation process supplements the competition protection functions under the TPA. This would allow the Minister to consider and, if necessary, set pro‐competitive limits to provide some opportunity for new entrants to purchase spectrum licences.

The electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) framework sets emission limits on devices capable of causing interference and specifies levels of immunity to emissions of electrical and electronic equipment supplied in Australia. Currently, the EMC framework applies to radiocommunications devices that are defined as such under the act, but has limited support in applying to other non‐radiocommunications devices which could cause, or be subject to, interference.

The proposed amendments would support the Spectrum Management Agency's EMC standards‐making power with respect to a range of devices including computers, navigation equipment, industrial equipment such as arc welding equipment and power tools, and spark ignition engines. Many of these devices have long histories of either causing interference to other devices or being susceptible to interference from other devices.
The proposed amendments are consistent with the SMA's responsibility for implementing and administering the EMC framework and for minimising the effects of interference.

The proposed extension of the SMA's standards making powers to include protection of the health and safety of persons who operate, work on or use radiocommunications transmitters or receivers, or are reasonably likely to be affected by their operation, enables the SMA to enforce compliance of radiocommunications devices, receivers and transmitters with such standards. It also harmonises radiocommunications legislation with telecommunications legislation.
The SMA is to continue arrangements with suitably qualified bodies, such as Standards Australia, for the development of standards.

Technical licence specifications in the act duplicate other technical regulatory powers of the SMA, notably the ability to set licence conditions, and lead to confusion as to which power should be used. The removal of these provisions will eliminate the confusion without materially affecting the SMA's powers in relation to technical regulation. Matters currently subject to such specifications will be converted to licence conditions and this mechanism will be used in future.
Madam President, the changes I have outlined will promote greater competition in telecommunications and will ensure that Australians benefit from advances in communications technology.
As part of the Government's commitment to continuing review of legislation, a more comprehensive review of the Radiocommunications Act will commence in the current financial year.
