Similarly, the amendments in the bill provide that the ACCC, before attempting an access code, must engage in public consultation. I think that perhaps goes a little way to addressing some of the issues Senator Margetts raised.

No, Senator Kemp, it does not. To take the first point, Senator Kemp says that under the Trade Practices Act the ACCC must consider the public interest. This sounds like an answer to my concerns; it is not, because the Trade Practices Act does not define what the public interest is. All that exists are rulings by the old Trade Practices Commission on things which could constitute public benefits. `Public benefits' are not necessarily the same as `public interest'. The most detailed of these rulings was in a 1991 case Re ACI Operations Pty. Ltd. Fourteen points were listed, the last being a rather vague statement: `Steps to protect the environment'. That is probably a little better than government policy on ecological sustainability when you have not got one.

This is not good enough. I am not happy that an unelected body such as the Trade Practices Commission or its successor, the hugely powerful ACCC, decides what constitutes public interest. Surely that should be the task of an elected body such as parliament. We should be defining the public interest and, should I say, protecting it. We are elected representatives of the Australian people. Leaving the ACCC to operate within that framework is bizarre. To allow the ACCC to decide what the public interest is to completely abrogate our responsibility as elected representatives.

Furthermore, the 14 points of public benefit, which I say is not the same as public interest, are overwhelmingly informed by the ideological belief that what is good for business is good for the public. The more efficient the economy, the happier the public. It ignores the many other non‐monetary issues that affect the public good that make up what we call the public interest. That is why the Greens are so concerned to see that public interest is better defined in legislation.

The government's response to our amendments were also contradictory. On the one hand the government and the ALP were complaining that we should not be defining public interest to the extent that we sought to in our amendment. The ALP protested that it was overly prescriptive. However, in one of his responses to me the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) told me that competition principles require governments to take into account a list of public interest matters when undertaking a review of regulations. The list includes policies relating to ecologically sustainable development, social welfare and equity considerations.

This is very similar to our amendment. I wonder, if you really believe that that is covered in the ACCC, why you have so much problem with our amendment. The reason is that it is not covered because all it refers to is your policies on ecological sustainability, which are close to zero.

There is another issue I would like to address and it is part of the national competition policy implementation agreement. All states and territories were required to prepare a schedule for review of all legislative restrictions on competition. I have with me the schedule prepared by the Queensland government. It goes through Queensland's legislation and identifies measures that restrict competition. This, of course, must be a bad thing—anything that restricts competition should be a bad thing, according to this. When you look at specific examples of what they consider to be measures that restrict competition, you see they are frequently things which are considered benefits to members of the public.

An example is licensing or registration requirements. That is explained as a practice which limits participation in industry to those persons or bodies that meet defined standards, qualifications or training. I can imagine there are lots of times when you really should have those kinds of requirements. This may be something that restricts competition, but it is also a very good thing indeed that this requirement exists. I am sure most people would be reassured to know that such standards are enforced.

Another example of anti‐competitive practice is business conduct restrictions. What are these? The Queensland Heritage Act 1992 apparently has sections which qualify as business conduct restrictions, and an example given is that Heritage Council approval is required before any development is allowed on heritage registered properties. Gosh, this must be a restriction on business, and this is what seems to be included. This is not a business conduct restriction; it is an appropriate regulation of activities which may damage properties which are part of Queensland cultural heritage. To term this as business restriction is truly the height of economic fundamentalism.

There are other examples which are worth quoting, and one of them is from the Child Care Act 1991, which regulates child-care centres. This, according to the review, is guilty of restricting competition in a number of ways. The bill prescribes matters such as qualifications of child‐care personnel. How outrageous! It sets out building and physical environment standards and food safety standards. Appalling! Senators, as the final indignity to competitive practice, the operation of child‐care facilities is prohibited in certain locations—that is, premises adjacent to a place where flammable materials or dangerous chemicals are manufactured or stored. So it is a restriction on business practice to not be allowed to put a child‐care facility next to a chemical waste dump. How awful!

What is clear from reading this document is that in many cases the push to increase competition involves dismantling regulations and practises which protect and promote the public interest. To put it bluntly, competition policy can frequently be against the public interest. How obscene it is to even consider the idea of relaxing regulations on child‐care facilities because they are restrictive of competition.

From reading this document, one also gets the feeling that competition policy, far from giving due weight to the public interest, may be used to undermine existing legislation in areas relating to the public interest such as environmental protection. As an example, the review of the Nature Conservation Act 1992 finishes with this rather chilling statement:

Prior to any national competition policy review commencing, further consideration is required to identify whether there are any restrictions in the various species conservation plans in place at that time that go beyond what is required for legitimate, natural resource management purposes.

So perhaps we will have the ACCC deciding on what is a legitimate resource management purpose. This is a time bomb we are looking at, a ticking time bomb which by 1998 will go off. In what way will it go off? Every single piece of legislation which does not conform to competition policy, which does not have a specific exemption, will somehow be made subject to competition policy. Therefore, be afraid, be very afraid. That is why, if we do not know what public interest is now, if we think somehow it will be all right on the night, we are deluding ourselves and we are deluding the people we have been set up to represent.

I would like to conclude this particular explanation by restating the point that I made in my second reading speech: the overriding concern of legislation which affects essential infrastructure such as electricity and water should be in the public interest. If competition serves the public interest, so be it, but it should not be taken as a given and it should be recognised that in some cases competition is against the public interest.

This bill, like so many that are increasing competition in the Australian economy, does not give due regard to public interest considerations and, indeed, explicitly equates competition with public interest. Our opposition to it remains, and I hope that some of these words have fallen on more fertile ears than we spoke to before in relation to the Labor Party because I believe that we all have responsibility.

I know it was the Labor Party that was involved with the competition legislation in 1995, and I know there is a level of embarrassment about that level of responsibility, but now is the time to face up to that responsibility and look at what we are doing to the future decisions that are going to be made that affect people on a very real level—the provision of electricity, the provision of water resources and heaven knows what else in the future. So I commend my amendments to the Senate and urge their support from my Senate colleagues.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Higher Education Funding for the 199799 Triennium

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I am switching hats at the moment and am speaking as the education spokesperson for the Australian Democrats. I refer to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs report before us. In fact, it is the higher education funding report for the 1997-99 triennium. Even after a brief glance at this report, I have to dispute some of its claims. Page 1 of the overview, section 2.2, states:
The government's funding package for higher education for years 1997-99 is both fiscally responsible and sensitive to the educational objectives and the planning horizons of the education sector.

If only it was. Of course, as we saw in this chamber today when we were debating the role of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) and the administration of her department, we realised that the higher education sector has undergone some of the most radical and profound changes that higher education has ever experienced in this country, with operating grants cuts and overall cuts in the magnitude of $1.8 billion.

I do not suggest for a minute that those cuts have been handled in a fiscally responsible or educationally sensitive manner—in fact, quite the contrary. I think that most of the experts or those in the know in the higher education sector, whether vice‐chancellors, academics, the National Tertiary Education Union or, in fact, students in their representative organisation, the National Union of Students, would argue very strongly that we have seen quite regressive changes made to the higher education sector over the last few months.

The report refers to some of those changes. Section 2.1 refers to operating grants. Again, this report seems to argue that the operating grants have been cut in a way that has given universities the time to plan and adapt and there will still be a net increase in funds for 1997. Again, I dispute the claims in this report. Many institutions first learnt of the cuts when they were mooted by the minister midyear last year and they were executed towards the end of last year, not giving institutions that much time to adapt because, as many of us would know, institutions in the higher education sector plan years in advance.

When it comes to the operation of faculties, courses or departments, many of those institutions had printed up their enrolment and other information many months before the budget changes were passed. Also, this report notes that the government's objective is to maintain undergraduate loads. The point that we should always remember is that this has been at the expense of postgraduate loads. It is very sad to see that the emphasis on not only teaching but research has been somewhat diminished under this government.

This report refers to other changes, as noted in section 2.13 which refers to opening up new areas for universities to gain revenue from diverse sources. That almost sounds like it is a really good and exciting thing for institutions when, in fact, institutions will be compensating for the massive cuts they have endured by introducing such regressive things as up‐front and full‐cost fees. As I mentioned in my speech today, University of Melbourne has set the benchmark with a $110,000 course for dentistry. I again ask the minister in this place, `How many poor kids are going to pay $110,000 so they can have a dentistry degree?' It is very sad that what this report does not reflect is that your ability to pay now determines your ability to study in this country.

On page 9, under the heading `A fair balance between public and private funding', this report in section 2.17 refers to changes to the higher education contribution scheme. As many of us would know, the HECS charges which were around $2,300 per annum have now been hugely increased. The humanities and various other courses now have a huge HECS debt of $3,300 per year. In relation to sciences, everybody would be aware of the reductions in science enrolments both at secondary school level and in higher education institutions. I am sure we all lament that but it did not stop the government putting a $4,700 fee per annum on courses such as science, maths, computing, engineering, processing and health sciences—all areas which, I might add, have experienced a reduction in enrolment applications this year. Law tops the list along with medicine at $5,500 per annum.

These are certainly not sensitive or fiscally responsible measures; they are measures promoted by government which is keen only on cost cutting and revenue raising. They are prepared to do it at the expense of not only this generation but future generations. It is very sad that it is now your bank balance that counts and not your merit when it comes to pursuing education in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —In tonight's adjournment debate I wish to take issue with the authors of an article that appeared in yesterday's issue of the Australian by the well‐known trio of euthanasia warriors: Singer, Kuhse and Baume, who allege that what I said to the Senate on 14 February 1997 was blatantly untrue. The questions also mix decisions which are traditionally held to be morally acceptable with those that are not. The eminent ethicists Tonti‐Fillipini, Fleming, Fisher and Krohn also make the telling point:

The apparent lack of objectivity and balance in the composition of the research team and the seemingly political nature of the project would not be lost on those doctors completing the questionnaire and may well have skewed the result. This view would have been confirmed by the inclusion of the two questions about the effects of legal interference in regard to medical practice.

When this very proposition was put to Professors Baume and Kuhse by me at the Senate hearing we received responses which reflect on their intellectual integrity. Allow me to quote from the Hansard . I asked:
How did you deal with the 36 per cent who did not respond? How did you factor that into your results, if at all?
Prof. Kuhse —We did. We recorded that they did not respond. That is the problem with any survey.
I followed up by asking:
Yes, I accept that. But don't you agree that the non‐respondents would be the most likely to be biased against the survey?
Professor Kuhse responded:
If I were an opponent of voluntary euthanasia I would have a strong incentive to fill in the questionnaire.
I then pointed out to Professor Kuhse as follows:
. . . can I quote from an article by Professor Baume published in the Medical Journal of Australia volume 161, 18 July 1994:—
in which Professor Baume wrote:
"The non‐respondents were less likely to agree that it is sometimes right for a doctor to take (active) steps to bring about a patient's death, as shown in Table 2."

Table 2 tells us those who responded `yes' from the respondents was 58 per cent but from the non‐respondents only 18.2 per cent—‐ a vast difference, wouldn't you agree? Were you aware of Professor Baume's findings before you made that comment?
Her answer was:
Prof.Kuhse —I should have been aware of those findings?
And further:
Prof.Kuhse —I reject the language of bias. What we have is a non‐response rate.

The fact that Professor Kuhse, supposedly an expert as a result of 17 years study, was not aware of her co‐author's study of only three years ago published in the same journal, the Medical Journal of Australia , is hard to accept. Professor Baume's failure to intervene to protect his own integrity and previous study was noteworthy. His silence despite knowing of his own study has left a very bad taste.
But what is really interesting and illuminating, indeed intriguing, is the comment by five academics for whom the article's authors, I am sure, have great regard. They commented as follows:
. . . all postal surveys are subject to some degree of non‐response bias.

Concentrate on the word `bias'. Allow me to emphasise: all postal surveys—not some but all—are subject to some degree of non‐response bias. So why this barefaced flat denial of a non‐response bias? Why the failure of Professor Baume to intervene?

Who were these five academics who told us that all postal surveys are subject to some degree of non‐response bias? Guess who. None other than Helga Kuhse, Peter Singer, Peter Baume, Malcolm Clark and Maurice Rickard—the very authors of the article. They had it in their very own article, which they denied to the Senate committee on the night that they gave evidence in camera. And Professor Kuhse was the principal author. The in camera evidence has now been made public, Senator Collins. I note your frowning.

When I asked my questions I did not have a copy of the article. If I had had a copy, Professor Kuhse may have been required to answer somewhat differently from what she did. Should we believe Professor Kuhse's own article on bias or her verbal evidence that refutes her own writing and the findings of the co‐author of only three years ago of which she claims she was unaware? He was dead wrong on both counts.

Bobby Liddle, conservative Aboriginal politician, was riding high in 1989. He was much in demand as a consultant and successfully sought preselection as the Country‐Liberal Party candidate for the sole House of Representatives seat. His success in this regard immediately set the CLP rumour mill rumbling. Rumours soon began circulating in Alice Springs and Darwin about Mr Liddle's alleged marital problems, so much so that the suitability of Mr Liddle's candidacy was placed on the agenda of the party's central council meeting in October that year. Two days before that meeting, Mr Stone, who was acting as an agent for a firm of Melbourne solicitors representing Mr Liddle in his matrimonial problems, wrote to his client, Mr Liddle, asking permission for his files—that is, his legal files—from Mr Stone's office to be made available to the CLP members at this meeting. Mr Stone received no such instructions, not surprisingly.

That did not stop him. He then took Liddle's file—I stress again this man was Liddle's lawyer—along to the meeting of the central council of the CLP where it was placed on the front table very prominently among a bundle of other files and papers. Needless to say, at that meeting Liddle was dumped as the Country Liberal Party candidate. He subsequently lodged a complaint against the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory with the Northern Territory Law Society.

The Ethics Committee of the Northern Territory Law Society found that Stone did not have Liddle's express authority to take his file to the meeting. It was not shown that anything from the file was revealed, but the committee said that the file's presence at the meeting had put Liddle `under undue and unfair pressure' at the meeting.

BREAK.PARA: The committee concluded that the complaint had been proved and that Stone's conduct was unprofessional because he had failed `to give undivided fidelity to his client's interests'. It found that Stone's conduct was wilful and showed reckless disregard for Liddle and found him guilty of professional misconduct. The Chief Minister was fined $1,000. He appealed to the Supreme Court and the law society later reduced its fine to $750 and its finding to one of unprofessional conduct. These sordid details are best documented in an article in the prominent legal newsletter Justinian in June 1995, which I seek leave to table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article says it all. Needless to say—and I might add this was the view of all the lawyers I spoke to in Darwin at the time, whether they were Labor or conservative—all the lawyers I spoke to thought that Shane Stone should have been struck off for what he had done with his client's files. I agreed with them. He is now the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. I think it is fair to say that a lot of people in the Northern Territory in relation to this sordid affair would properly describe the Chief Minister's behaviour on this occasion as despicable.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Higher Education: Science Enrolments Science and Technology

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to discuss science enrolments, and I am still reeling from Senator Bob Collins's speech. The university applications and enrolments are in and, as we have discussed over many days and weeks in this chamber, they do demonstrate an overall decline in demand for places in all states except Queensland. Of course, science, engineering and technology courses have been particularly hard hit.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite pledges from both the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) and the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) to review the higher HECS charges for science and any possible or detrimental impact on science enrolments, there has still been no action in this regard. It is notable that, despite considerable forewarning about the Austudy means tests and the difficulties with that, the government prevaricated until it was almost too late and certainly until it became quite embarrassing. But this time we are warning the government so it can avoid further embarrassment, especially in this area of science. The evidence is now there. We are calling on the government for some action.

On last Sunday's Face to Face program, the Minister for Science and Technology failed to say that one of the most important aspects of encouraging young people to enter science, engineering and technology courses—and I do acknowledge that he is very keen to increase enrolments in those areas—was the current and present appearance of a future in science, and the future does not look too great if you are an aspirant in the science field. Without being able to see a good professional future, it is little wonder that young people are turning away from that field in favour of more secure professions.

Increasing HECS fees for science and technology courses does not make it any more attractive to pursue science courses and science based careers. It certainly highlights a fact that has been highlighted by eroding academic salaries, conditions and opportunities available for any young person contemplating a future in science, engineering or technology.

So what is required now on behalf of the government is a serious commitment that would support innovative science programs in schools and create a vital research community. We believe the government has failed to address the fundamental problem of funding cuts, infrastructure decline, personnel losses and, of course, the lack of real job prospects for young people who are considering science based careers.

A strong and vibrant research community that has adequate funding and a long-term perspective will attract young people because they will see that there is the opportunity to pursue excellence and their imagination in that way. We must also ensure that there is sufficient training through schooling and universities to provide the passion, the intel lect and the imagination necessary for this research excellence.

The government now has a choice and it is certainly the time to act. However, its recent actions are not particularly a good indication for the future. The recent announcement of a five per cent reduction in government funding for universities between 1997 and 1999 is a further kick. With the long‐awaited increases to some salaries of university academics, the effective funding to universities will be further eroded because money will be taken out to pay those salaries. On top of the cuts that have already been imposed by the government, this is not a good sign.

I also note that this government has made significant attempts to link research with industry and has attempted to seek increased funding of research from the private sector. There is a role for this form of collaborative funding in research conducted in Australia. However, we also need to realise that, when private enterprises seek collaboration in government funded research, they are seeking a contribution from the government for their research goals. These goals may not always be in line with what is beneficial for the community in the long term.

We need to ensure that government research funds are not used in disproportionate amounts to subsidise the research of the private sector at the expense of basic research funding. So the allocation of increased funding for the Australian Research Council targeted at collaborative research does not necessarily further the goals of basic research funding in this country.

Harnessing science for wealth creation is short-sighted and unlikely to bring about the long-term rewards of innovative basic research. What is needed is a balance between the core of curiosity led research and targeted programs to take the particular fruits of that core research to market. It is not reasonable to expect the private sector to pursue research from which they cannot identify outcomes. Their horizon and, of course, their imperative are somewhat different. The benefits of government funded core research are that the community benefits through improved education and, of course, jobs and wealth are created from the private sector applying the research that would not otherwise have been undertaken.

The government also appears to have perhaps downgraded the role of science and technology in the political hierarchy. The appointment of Dr John Stocker as the chief scientist and chairman of the Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council is at a different level from that of his predecessor. His appointment is now under the minister, Peter McGauran, rather than under the Prime Minister. This appears to mean that the government has decided that other areas are more important and perhaps science has been downgraded. I look forward to hearing alternative arguments from Minister McGauran.

Perhaps the federal government should consider the approach of the Victorian government, where a commitment and `political priority' have been given to science and engineering, recognising their potential for the future. But they do not shy away from the funding cuts that the Victorian government has made to education at all levels and its attacks on student representative organisations and universities. At least Jeff Kennett is talking about investigating where we have gone wrong with science and how we can encourage people to pursue science based careers.

It is interesting to note that the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) said last week that he was confident that research and development funding would be quarantined from the next budget cuts. This recognises the severe impact of the last round of budget cuts on this sector and the place of this sector, with its valuable and important role in Australian industry. There is the opportunity for jobs and development in new industries based on Australian research. The government has a role in getting these new industries going. We should consider industry planning, funding alternatives and setting some long-term national priorities. There is a place for schemes, such as the factor F scheme, seed funding and other financial measures for targeted developments. Further cuts would certainly be sending the wrong message.

The announcement by the Minister for Science and Technology to make 1997 the year of youth in science with an allocation of $12 million over three years for youth focused science activities is a good start. It is a worthy initiative and certainly one that the Democrats support. Unfortunately, the detail of the $12 million allocation shows that the money will be spent on prizes, training journalists and media outlets as well as some youth activities. A spokeswoman for the minister was reported as saying in the Canberra Times on 9 January this year that the minister meant to say that the bulk of the $12 million would go to youth focused activities. Clearly, that is not good enough.

This lack of action signals a tragic understanding of this government's attitude to science and technology. We must focus on these present attacks on science and technology in universities and research institutions and consider the consequences for Australia's future. It is not good enough for the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs to blame the universities or the Minister for Science and Technology to blame the schools for the reduction in enrolments or the number of people pursuing science based paths. The government must address waning science and technology education at all levels through funding cuts, infrastructure decline, personnel losses and the lack of real job prospects for young people considering a career in the science and technology field.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on the adjournment debate on the very serious matter of welfare fraud. As Australia begins to rebuild its economy, it is extremely important for all taxpayers that those people who receive welfare benefits—social security payments of one sort or another—do so based on genuine need. The coalition is committed to fairness in this scheme. It is believed by them and all of us that it is unfair to those people who are genuinely in need, and the taxpayers of Australia, to allow people to rort the social security system.

BREAK.PARA: The previous government left the system riddled with instances of fraud. We are attempting to restore accountability to the system, which follows our election commitment, in which we said:
The Coalition is committed to taking all possible steps to prevent fraud—
and to ensure—
that only those who are eligible under the Social Security Act are receiving those payments.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) is determined to restore the community's confidence in this system. She has directed attention and resources to tackling the problem and very recently reported on the first report on welfare fraud, which was tabled in this parliament. The findings very clearly justify the government's fraud control strategy.

It revealed that taxpayers are now saving over $10 million every single week as a result of the review conducted over the last six months of last year. Total debt recoveries in that time were $175 million, which is an increase of 49 per cent on the same time last financial year. Compliance reviews increased by 28.7 per cent to almost $1.5 million, resulting in an identification of overpayments during that time of $105 million.

In my state of South Australia, social security spending is particularly significant. Almost 40 per cent of South Australians—that is, 578,000 people—receive social security payments totalling $15½ billion per year. This is the largest percentage of any Australian state population in receipt of these benefits. While South Australia comprises 8.1 per cent of Australia's total population, the state actually accounts for 9.5 per cent of Australia's total social security payments.

In South Australia, Senator Newman's review of benefits revealed that, in the 122,000 reviews conducted by the department, almost $1 million per week of ongoing savings was identified. There were 13,000 cases of overpayment. Most importantly to me, the public showed that they were very keen to be involved in the identification of welfare fraud, finding those people who are taking benefits that are more properly directed to the needy recipients in this country. Much of the information provided to Senator Newman's department relating to welfare cheats came from 26,000 reports received from members of the public.

As I said, our focus is on the government directing funds to those who are genuinely needy. This approach stands in very stark contrast to the one of our predecessors. When Mr Keating had his hands on the levers, we had an absolutely woeful half-hearted record on social security compliance. The data‐matching program that was introduced in 1991 on the basis that it would lead to savings of over $300 million per year in its first year of introduction saved only $17 million. That is $17 million of a projected $300 million in savings.
The former Minister for Social Security, Mr Baldwin, boasted in 1995 that we were leading the world in social security compliance efforts. In October 1994, he claimed in the House of Representatives:
The government has implemented a range of measures to ensure that social security payments are properly targeted to those in need . . .

Three years later, in South Australia alone, we have identified $1 million per week in savings and $10 million per week nationally. That was an amazing claim for him to have made three years ago. Like his former leader, he was trying to tell people that, in terms of social security fraud detection, that was as good as it got.

Senator Newman's six‐monthly report—I should correct my earlier statement; it was her second report and not her first—indicated that, just like other claims of `this is as good as it gets', it was a hollow promise. Labor sat on its hands when it came to fraud control in the social security system, and it simply did not put enough resources in to stay a jump ahead of the welfare cheats. The extent of the problem that was left has been revealed in these reports by Senator Newman.

So the message to welfare cheats from this government is: if you are minded to cheat the system, if you do not play by the rules, we will catch you. The message to taxpayers is: we are targeting your money better, we are making recipients more accountable and we are making sure that welfare payments are not wasted. I believe that welfare is a justifiable payment to those families in need and I am sure that all Australian taxpayers would agree that we are prepared to pay for social security support for those who are in genuine need. But we all—very correctly—resent paying for a system that rewards the dishonest and profits the cheats.

More focused welfare payments will restore integrity to, and return public confidence in, the system. Also, properly understanding the way the true picture develops on welfare means that the government can plan and more effectively run the welfare system. It will make the social security system work better and it will make policy decisions based on correct assumptions, numbers that are true and budget estimates that are truthful. That is part of the coalition's promise to this country and it will return good administration in social security for all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address the issue of suicide in Australia and, in particular, the problems facing our young people. As you are all aware, youth suicide is one of the major causes of death among young people, rated against car accidents, drownings and poisonings. Suicide now claims more young men's lives than car accidents do.

SPEECH.PARA: However, as many of you may be aware, the statistics presented are not a true reflection of the current situation. Suicide will not be officially noted unless it has been proven beyond reasonable doubt. Many families and friends, for a whole range of reasons, will not characterise the death of a loved one as a suicide. The number of attempted suicides is enormous and unfortunately young men succeed in their more violent attempts to end their lives. Recently, a rural suicide prevention project estimated that 80,000 people attempt suicide each year.

What remains true is that young people are dying at a much faster rate and that is a reflection on our society. The question I often contemplate is the level of stress that young people face today and how that compares to even a generation ago. At the moment, over 25,000 young people are homeless in Australia. The fact that Australia is being cited as one of the leaders in youth homelessness and youth suicide gives impetus to the desperate need for governments of all persuasions to effect change.

Our indigenous young people are still facing disproportionate levels of incarceration, arrest, inadequate access to health services, and abuse and violence against them. They are faced with a society that not only rejects their youth but also their culture and their self‐determination. Young people in 1997 need a feeling of identity and belonging and, if this government continues to ignore the holistic view of youth suicide, many young people in this country will continue to have feelings of failure, anger, isolation and hopelessness.

The coalition government has, to date, ignored the ramifications of its narrow‐minded and expedient programs on young people. For example, recently when I was visiting a refuge for young people I was told of the problems facing the young people who had just been taken off the defunded LEAP program. For these already socially isolated young people, the effect was dramatic. Suddenly they had nowhere to go; they were unable to finish the project they had started and they were definitely not involved in any consultation about changes to labour market programs.

The coalition government believes in telling young people what to do, instead of listening. It is made up of patronising parties that rely on an antiquated view of young people being seen and not heard. They are parties that continuously widen the gap between those who have opportunity and those who have none. They are parties that make charities, families, non‐government organisations and advocacy groups cope with increasing pressures that young people are facing. And why is it that young people are not being heard? Perhaps it is due to the fact that they cannot vote and there is no medium for them to want to, or be able to, change the process that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his ideologues espouse.

BREAK.PARA: I note with interest that the government is conducting a forum on this issue this week. It certainly appears to fill the criteria of the standard consultation that the coalition government uses—lots of media and big names. Obviously, politicians from all sides of the chamber support an initiative that hopefully will result in some recommendations that will improve the situation for young people. We hope the Prime Minister starts these consultations with young people, in particular, young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, as he promised he would do in his lead‐up to the election. It is our greatest hope that the recommendations produced by the youth suicide forum will have a direct link to budget appropriations. That is when we will know the extent of this government's commitment to the welfare of young people in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 15 January 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister intend to scrutinise the environmental credentials of the Perth airport bidders; if so, how will this be done; if not, why not.
(2) Is the Minister aware that the Conservation Council of Western Australia has prepared a written questionnaire to be answered by all bidders for the Perth airport.
(3) Is the Minister aware that the Conservation Council of Western Australia has been unsuccessful in obtaining the names of six of the seven Perth airport bidders from the Office of Asset Sales.

(4) Is the Minister aware that one of the bidders, Australian Pacific Airports, has announced its bid for ownership of the Perth airport and, at a public meeting on 26 November 1996, agreed to complete a questionnaire on its position in relation to the natural environment.

(5) Does the Minister agree that this gives Australian Pacific Airports an advantage in the bidding process, as only its position on natural environment issues can be publicised; if so, will the Minister release the names of the other six bidders for Perth airport so that the questionnaire can be put to the other bidders.
(6) Does the Minister agree that the public has a right to know the environmental credentials of all the bidders so a comparison can be made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A letter from Senator the Hon. Ian Campbell in respect of the request from the Conservation Council of WA was referred to me for response. This letter was responded to on my behalf by Dr Kemp, the Minister assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation.

Dr Kemp's response to Senator Campbell explains that environmental considerations have been given a strong emphasis in the bidding process. Those consortia currently participating in Stage 2 of the bidding process were required to submit binding bids to the Commonwealth by 30 January 1997. As a part of those bids, bidders were required to provide:

PARA.TAB: details of environmental planning proposed for the airport over the next five years; and
a depiction in diagrammatic form of the environmental management structure proposed.

ANSWER.PARA: Further, one of the ongoing privatisation objectives, against which all bids are being assessed, is that each Airport Lessee Company acts to promote the economic development of its Phase 1 airport in a way that is responsive to the interests of users, the environment and the region in which the airport is located.

In addition to this, there will be a number of obligations that will be incumbent on successful bidders as a part of the post‐privatisation regulatory regime. In particular, the successful Airport Lessee Company will be required to submit to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, for approval by that Minister, a detailed draft environmental strategy within 12 months of the acquisition of the lease. This environmental strategy must relate to a period of five years. An updated environmental strategy must be submitted before the expiry of any existing environmental strategy. The Airport Lessee Company will also have to comply with any Environmental Regulations made under the Airports Act 1996.

(2) I am aware that the Conservation Council of WA sought the identity of the parties bidding for Perth airport. I am also aware that the Conservation Council prepared a written questionnaire to be answered by all bidders for Perth airport.
(3) I am aware that the Conservation Council of WA was unsuccessful in obtaining the identities of bidders from the Office of Asset Sales.

The Government's approach to such requests in the lead‐up to the closing date for bids has been to neither confirm nor deny the participation of consortia in Stage 2 of the bidding process. This approach has been adopted in order to protect the confidentiality of the bidding process.

(4) I am aware that the Australian Pacific Airports Corporation (APAC) has announced its bid for ownership of Perth airport and has agreed to complete a questionnaire on its position in relation to the environment.

(5) For the reasons outlined above, whilst bidders are free to announce their bidding intentions, I do not feel that it is appropriate for the Government to disclose the identity of the bidders for Perth airport. Completion of the questionnaire by APAC does not, in itself, give APAC an unfair advantage in the bidding process as it has been open to all bidders for Perth airport to approach the Conservation Council of WA in order to discuss how they propose to deal with environmental issues.

(6) The identity of bidders was not made public at the time for the reasons stated above. It is important, however, to recognise that environmental issues have been given considerable weight in the bidding process. Further, the post‐privatisation regulatory regime is designed to ensure that the operators of the Phase 1 airports deal with environmental issues in the appropriate manner.
